text: From a 12 oz. bottle, poured into a glass.  Lovely smooth amber color, with a fingers-width of creamy white head. Settled after the first couple of sips to a fine cap, with delicate lacing.  Initial scent was bright, citrusy, with pine. Taste carried the same—initial brightness, with a resinous base tone. Settled into a pleasing bitterness, like good tea, that gradually settled to a doughy finish. As it warmed, the bitterness—the hops, I presume—shouldered its way to the front.  Mouth-feel was lively. Robust carbonation, with a notable presence, despite not feeling particularly thick.  A fine beer, it seems to be.

12 oz. Bottle, 12 weeks old. Clear, medium amber color. Light, non offensive hoppy aroma. Taste is light, good introduction to the IPA style. Feel is easy going, hops linger briefly. Overall, very pleasant, would pair well with most any food. Would buy again.

Had on tap at Hoffbrau bar and grill Westminster, CO  On arrival 1 finger of dense white head was present, sitting on top of a light amber clear body. Lacing is left. Nice looking beet.  Aroma is bright with some American WC hops and a lightly sweet maltiness. Definitely a hoppy beer, but I appreciate the amber notes that I can pick up.  Taste follows the nose but brings an actual caramel maltiness. An herbal piney bitterness is present, but the bitterness fades a bit giving way for a sweet darker doughy maltiness. This is actually pretty dang good. Very balanced woth a light sweetness following some bright and bitter hop character.  Feel is big and malty but not huge. A bit more on the crisp side despite the mouthcoating malt presence. Definitely versatile, but leaning toward a full bodied summer beer.  Overall, this beer was pretty impressive, and I'm not sure why I haven't given it a shot yet. Amber "pale ales" are a very nice beer style, but they could use a bit of a marketing revamp if I do say so myself.

12oz can  Sierra Nevada Pale Ale body is a dark amber hue and a slightly aggressive pour produced a 2-finger off-white head. Just a small amount of lacing was left behind. The nose is dominated by citrus and pine hops. The taste matches the nose with a light amount of caramel malt in the background. The bitterness from the pine and citrus hops lingers. The Ale is medium bodied with a moderate carbonation.  Overall, Sierra Nevada Pale Ale is the classic example of an American Pale Ale.

Bottled On: 06-27-22  A - Medium golden amber color with light carbonation and thin lacing.  S - Light earthy spice with faded floral and citrus.  T - Light biscuity malt with earthy spice, citrus, and light floral while finishing balanced.  M - Big medium body with gentle carbonation ands leaves a coating of earthy floral citrus in the mouth.  O - This beer is (7) months old and still drinking well. Once again, another beer I've had several times in the past but never reviewed? Wassup with that?

Poured from a 12 ounce bottle into a pint glass. Nice deep amber ale with a white head that leaves decent lacing all the way through. Smells of piney hops and grapefruit citrus. Taste follows - piney and fruity. Feel is medium carbonation and rolls well with full body. Overall, an excellent and classy every day or session pale ale. Best in Class.

L: Pours golden clear with two fingers of head. Trickles eventually down to just a surface coating.  S: Hoppy bitterness. Slight citrus.  T: Bitterness amplified. Tangerine.  F: Fizzy bitter pine resin.  O: A nice time-tested pale ale. Inspired many other beers.

Pours a beautiful dark gold with a frothy head. Smell is lemongrass and bread. Taste starts off with lemongrass and then morphs into a bready backbone with a slight lingering bitterness. Tastes exactly how an American Pale Ale should. Perfect for the style.

Translucent gold copper. Crisp, piney, and fruity. Light citrus and spice, bready malt with herbal undertones. It's been years since I had this beer, and it's not nearly as intense in flavor as I remember. How times have changed. It's still a decent beer after all this time, well balanced and unassuming. Here's to the old days!
I really don't think you can improve on this beer. The only pale Ale I think is better than summit epa. Just timeless. Delicious.

After 40 years it has become a classic brew. Is it perfect? Just about. It somehow eluded me until some You Tube reviews showed up... It's kind of like if you had one last beer to ever drink which would it be... ? Right now at age 70 I'd ask for a Sierra Nevada Pale Ale.. So well balanced... if you have never tried it... it is a must pleasure.
My go-to pale ale when I need a consistent and affordable beer. A good choice to bring to a party as it is sure not to offend anyone
A classic pale ale from a great brewer. Amber color and fresh bready aroma. Taste begins with floral Cascade hops and finish is smooth and malty. Moderate carbonation. A good one!

Appearance: Pours a golden bet color with a thick white foam head. Retains nicely. Some sticky lacing left behind.  Aroma: Grainy malts and some slight fruity notes.  Taste: Citrus hops up front, with a subtle but notable bitterness. Malts in the background. A clean finish.  Overall: this is a classic. You can't go wrong with it. L

Love it...forget the nostalgia (because that is there)...it is just spot on, every time. Looks beautiful in a glass when cold! Was my first brush with this kind of taste and I still love it 20 years later.
The gold standard for American pale ales. Crisp, bitter but not heavy. Classic!

Poured from a 12 oz bottle dated 5/24/2022 into a Willi Becher pint glass. L - Pours a medium amber color with a medium white head that leaves lacing on the glass as it dissipates. S - Smells of pine and citrus. T - Taste matches the smell, piney and citrusy. F - Medium body and carbonation. O - Probably the benchmark for a Pale Ale. I could drink these all afternoon.

poured from a 12oz bottle into a floyds’ pint glass. pours an amber color with two finger fluffy white foam head. fresh spruce tips, pine sap and slight citrus on the nose. taste is very piney and slightly bitter with a citrus finish. plenty of malt to go with the hops (and hop bitterness) but nothing that overpowers or doesn’t allow the pine-forward hops to shine. it’s very well balanced with a full mouthfeel. it’s been a little bit since i’ve had a SNPA and a great reminder of why it such a classic APA.
The poster child Pale Ale, although I prefer Dale's.
I will update this review. But, simply a fantastic warm to hot weather moderate ABV pale ale. Really good choice if you wanna great tasting beer without feeling the effects of 8 or 9%

Hard to rate for someone who just got serious about beer a few years ago. All time classic. Very balanced. No off flavors. Also there have been so many aggressive, pushing the envelope beers that it seems quaint. Honestly I’d drink it any day, which is what matters.

I saw the the rating on this site, outstanding, so I decided to try it. What a flop, little carbonation and the taste doesn't last. On the plus side, full body and nice dark gold color. Overall, an average beer.
Smells nothing. Yeast taste and very low carbonate

Thin brief rocky white head; poor cap retention; thin ring; no lace; deep gold/pale amber liquid with excellent clarity. Lemon grass nose. Semi bitter lemon peel; pine; firm malt base. Medium light body, moderate minus carbonation; no astringency. An ok PA; good balance; easy drinking with good flavor.
The perfect American Pale Ale!
I appreciate this beers bready malt and herbal hop flavors. Definitely a top pale ale.
All the superlatives are well deserved. It set the standards for the style over 20 years ago and remains just as relevant today.
Perfect all around pale ale. This is the GOAT for pale ales. Not a IPA, not a APA but crisp refreshing, not to hoppy or too dry. Look is basic but the smell and taste are phenomenal.
Pretty good pale ale has a nice bitterness from the hops ha nice flavor and tastes great!

Semi-clear amber color with a foamy head and some nice lacing. I denote yeast and light hops. Above average with a nice carbonation and dry finish. This Pale Ale seems to be good every time I have one. I recommend this one to my friends all the time.

This is a really pretty beer- dense froth, rich color, bubbles galore. Beyond that, I’m not impressed. Almost nothing on the nose. The taste is mostly bitter without a great finish. I like that they support NPR, but this isn’t a beer that makes the rotation.

L - Poured from a 12 oz bottle into a standard pint glass at roughly 50 degrees. Pours a clear amber color with an off-white 1/2 finger head on a tame pour. Minor lacing that doesn’t stay. Head quickly reduces down to a light film.  S - Pleasant pine hops and citrus zest. Very nice light flavor scents overall.  T - Taste follows scent. Sweet fruit zest paired with piney and floral hops. Very light and refreshing. There’s a nice sweet flavor that I can’t pinpoint that comes through as well. On second thought, it’s grapefruit. Very nice addition.  F - Not a lot of carbonation and a lighter mouthfeel.  O - Overall this is a solid beer. Very good for regular drinking, and a standout for outdoors and camping. The sweet and bitter flavors provide a nice mix. I am by no means a hophead, but this is a nice, acceptable amount of hops and bitterness. It’s in my regular rotation and I would definitely recommend it to others.

Sierra Nevada pale ale was introduced in 1980, this is a historic craft beers of the world that helped shape the craft beer game that we know & love. This is also one of the first beers I've ever tried and the review will be a bit biased as a result.  Look: Thin 1.5 finger - off white/ cream color head and a cloudy orange in color.  Smell: Smells wonderful - citrus, barley malt, sweet piney aroma (I wish I could make a perfume out of this fragrance).  Taste: Very refreshing - hop forward with a punch of citrus and pleasantly bitter hops, piney and grapefruit notes, mild caramel-like sweetness and crisp clean water.  Feel: So smooth - Medium soft & fluffy ale body with a mildly sweet and semi-dry finish.  Overall, it's an exceptional beer!  ABV: 5.6% | IBU: 38
A perfect every day beer.

Pours a deep-ish golden-orange, with a nice finger and a half, foamy white head. The head has lasting impact in my glass, lasting the entirety of the drink, well over 15 minutes. Long lines of bubbles run up the glass. Looks amazing. Thick generous lacing lines the entirety of the glass as it empties.  Smells of wheat, bread, floral hops with a touch of bitterness. It’s clean and fresh smelling. Some piney notes, notes of grassy straw. General zesty citrus in the background. It’s as clean and classic as you can get.  Some have described SNPA as a mix between an APA and an IPA, but this is just straight up APA for me with mild balancing bitterness. Gentle floral hop, grassy flavours wash over the tongue before revealing straight up sweet caramel malt, some tasty bready wheat notes, and the citrus I notice here, mostly grapefruit. Gentle but tasty. It’s so straight up clean that it almost feels more complex than it is. SNPA has never been described as the absolute boldest, biggest smash your face flavour beer, but it isn’t any worse for it. When you want that clean, crisp, yet flavourful and subtle APA, this is the taste you think of in your mind. It is your classic example personified in an actual beer.  It’s well carbonated but not super strong; resulting in a nicely smooth, mildly creamy sip. Subtle medium long finish, that leaves just a hint of bitterness and lightly roasted grains on your tongue. Finishes clean and semi-dry. It’s so easy drinking and clean I’d consider this light bodied myself.  When thinking and comparing this beer to others, I want to give it a higher ranking than I ultimately put here. There is more aspects to some beers than just the categories here. SNPA is a work-horse, a beer that can be easily drank all night, be enjoyed by quite literally every single beer drinker no matter what style preference you have, and is a super clean straight up benchmark of the style.

Had it on cask at Brick Store, Decatur, Georgia, March 2022. I've never been an IPA or even a pale ale guy. The mouthfeel from the hops just doesn't do it for me. Having it on cask is an entirely different story. Some (not all) previous cask tries on my part conveyed a beer devoid of all carbonation, mouthfeel and coldness all in the name of purity. Now comes Sierra Pale on cask and the difference could not be more distinct. Maybe the best mouthfeel ever and then you get all of the taste profile and aroma that you would want, plus just about the perfect level of carbonation, and there you have it.

Bottle dated 9-28-2021 Appearance: Cloudy amber color with generous-sized, thick, off-white head that slowly faded. A nice-looking beer.  Smell: Mild piney aromas and mild bready notes. The nose is fairly mild, but the beer was bottled over 4 months ago.  Taste: Some mildly sweet fruit notes and some faint pine notes present in the flavor profile. The beer has a mildly sweet initial taste which dies off somewhat with some lingering bitter hop notes.  Mouth-feel: Fairly light-bodied with a fairly generous level of carbonation.  Overall: A good beer that I've had before but never reviewed. I suspect the beer being over 5 months ago may have impacted it's impression so I may seek out a fresh example and review it again.

Look: Pours a translucent, bright orange with a two finger head of soapy, off-white foam. Laces the glass pretty well.  Aroma: Caramel malt and strong pine resin. Very bitter on the nose. Slightly tropical with mild hints of orange zest. Fairly straightforward.  Taste: Pleasantly bitter upfront with a warm, dry resinous pine sap note. Goes tropical midpalate with bitter-sweet flavors of orange zest and peppery grapefruit rind. Fades out into savory flavors of brown sugar and toffee.  Feel: Thirst quenching. Medium bodied, moderately carbonated.  Overall: I'm very surprised it took me so long to get around to reviewing this one since I drink it all the time. Sierra Nevada pale ale is one of my all time favorite beers. You honestly can't go wrong with this - an absolute classic American pale ale.
One of the better ‘starter’ IPAs. Highly recommend

Probably the most amazing easy drinking and perfect for its style beer ever brewed! It’s a NorCal classic and a beer that I respect for it’s consistent quality and family ownership! Cheers my friends!
A bit too dour Hops are bitterish and a bit sour not a repeat buy for me
1/12/22 Clean, crisp, low alcohol. Perfect for it’s style. Nice summer beer but prefer something bolder (ie Torpedo). A solid offering.

Too bitter for me. I remember liking this when I was younger, last Sierra I had was 18 years ago. I do like how crisp and refreshing it is. Glad I bought it though, as I continue my search for the best beer for me I can buy on regular basis. Sam Adams is next, then anchor steam. Gonna keep trying and digging the journey.  Lighter than an IPA which is nice, as IPAs I am not a fan. But 805 tastes better than Sierra. I don’t understand why this is rated as Outstanding. I don’t have to however. Again, I am a Lager guy.  So I am on the 3rd Sierra, and this beer is getting better. It’s quite a satisfying buzz too. Think I need to look for stronger beers.  Ok on my 5th Sierra. Gonna drink the whole 6. It gets better. Past the 3rd. Still, my too bitter comment is honest. Probably why I prefer lagers and stouts. But I get it. Sierra is a great beer buzz.
Dark amber with white head. Light citrus and pine smell and taste. Hops not over powering. Easy drinking.

Pours semi-clear amber color with a two finger foamy head with nice lacing. Smell of yeast, light hops, honey. Flavor notes of biscuit, berry with a light hop bitterness on the finish. Above average mouth feel with nice carbonation and dry finish. You can't go wrong with this Sierra Nevada work horse! This Pale Ale is a tried and true offering that delivers every time!

Pours a clear golden color, frothy white head, spotty lacing. Pine, grapefruit and some caramel hit the nose, taste buds get that too. Medium bodied, carbonation is spot on. This really is a great beer!

12oz bottle dated 5/26/21 poured into a pint glass on 7/13/21.  Pours 1" of off-white, foamy head. Translucent golden-brown color.  Aromas of pine cones, caramel, and citrus.  Taste follows the nose with some drying and bittering in the finish. Mostly pine with some lemon notes.  Effervescent and slightly astringent mouthfeel. Crisp, refreshing, and medium-bodied.  Delicious with a clean and focused pine hop profile. Well-balanced malts and crisp body makes it an easy-drinking, flavorful beer.
Cerveza de color ambar con una leve espuma de retención media. Cuerpo ligero y carbonatación media. Aroma a naranja, limón y mango. Sabor dulce afrutado con un leve amargor en su final.

12 oz bottle bought from a room temp. shelf on 8/29, refrigerated then consumed from a tulip glass same day/ bottle date 6/11/21. Nice amber color, very clear/no haze. Off white head about 1 finger high. Reasonable longevity, some lacing. Smells maltier than I expected but taste is a very nice balance of malts and hops. Overall a nice Pale tha tis a good benchmark to revisit periodically to recalibrate my ratings of other similar beers.
Very good beer. Especially nice for cold weather; wouldn't work on the beach. Strikes that rare balance between flavorful and palatable. One of the best widely-available beers on the market.

12 Oz. bottle into pint glass. Look: Amber color, 1 finger head that maintained some structure for most of the drinking session, good lacing Smell: Bready with hints of grapefruit. Pleasant Taste: Medium bitter hop flavor, some citrus in background. Feel: A tongue tingler, flavor stays after swallowing. Overall: A extremely enjoyable drink. I am not familiar with style but I would absolutely buy this one again. Pairs best with meat pies and hamburgers, cheddar cheese. A banana pudding would be interesting.

My turn to rate the old favorite and I can’t believe it either. Citrus, piney hops dominate the smell and it pours a rich, copper hue with some head. Tastes a lot like the aroma with the piney, fruity taste, a good little kick at 37 ibu’s, and a solid malt backbone. It works together in near perfect harmony and the mouthful is luxurious and somewhat creamy which is a characteristic I seem to like. One of the oldest but still one of the best Pale Ales you can get with a nice price and good availability, you literally can’t go wrong.

It's definitely not at all bad, even pretty good still but after having it again now I realize how completely fucking boring this beer truly is in 2021. Acclimated is way more flavorful. I suppose it could be argued it's a "boring" style even but idk. Still kind of a snoozefest, will look forward to seeing at ball games though

Can't believe its taken me so long to review this Bar Setting Classic! Honestly, I know I'm crazy but can't say I've had this more than a handful of times over the years either.  Gladly, I've waited as my palate has developed. Several years ago at the height of my haze craze I'd probably have unjustly given much lower marks....but today while drinking I thoroughly enjoy this beer and will be back for more.
Hazy golden with a strong lacy cream colored head. Light aroma with resin notes. Bright balanced IPA with smooth mouthfeel. Very above average and could be used as a session with a bit of a kick.

This is a 12oz bottle poured into a 20oz. weizen glass somewhat aggressively. The look is so perfect, an orange, clear ale with heavy carbonation and one finger of white foam that does not recede. The aroma is sweet citrus, bitter pine, and a light malt presence. The flavor is citrus and pine mostly with a light caramel malt presence. The mouthfeel is a medium texture that is dry, crisp, with a light bitter hop finish. There is a reason this is a classic, there is a nice balance in the flavors and the aroma making this pale ale very enjoyable. This was very refreshing after several hours of yard work today.

Light transparent amber color with a bouncy off-white head. Mild notes of pine and citrus on the nose. Malts are very mellow and approachable. Great classic malt flavor with just a touch of bitter hops. Slightly fruity, slightly piney. One of the most refreshing and quaffable pale ales i've had.

Bottled 4/29/21  Man, it's a shock to me that I've never actually reviewed this legendary brew. One of my gateway beers into craft in 2018, which despite not being very long ago feels like a lifetime ago for a younger person such as myself. So given the site-wide tasting today, it's time to give this old classic/consistent go-to beer at restaurants a proper review  Pours a slightly cloudy amber gold with 2 fingers of white head that fades to a thin cap and leaves minimal lacing  For me personally, the nose is always the star of the show for this beer, really tying it all together with an exceptional balance of malt and hops. I'm picking up on aromas of piney hops, caramel malt, pithy grapefruit, orange zest, and light lemon  Oh man, what an iconic tasting beer. As I said, not quite as incredible as the aroma, but still nicely balanced. On the front end of the sip I'm tasting fresh piney hops, lemon peel, orange zest, bready malt, and light caramel. The swallow brings notes of pithy grapefruit, bready malt, toasted grain, floral peppery hops, and orange zest  A light medium body pairs with gentle tingling carbonation, resulting in a crisp yet full beer. Finishes mostly dry with a light spice to offset the malt  A beer more than the sum of its parts, an institution even. It's a classic for a reason, and I'm glad we have a day to celebrate it. Cheers!

Sampling a chilled 12 oz bottle poured into my snifter. The beer is packaged 5/2021. The beer pours a clear amber to copper color with an eggshell white fluffy head of 3 cm that fades slowly to a rocky surface layer and some clingy lattice. The foam sticks around as a sturdy surface layer throughout the tasting. Some very fine lazy streams of carbonation are rising to the surface. The aroma is some pine notes and a bit of grapefruit rind dominate, but I do get a little caramel and grainy bread note coming through the nose. First sip reveals a medium body and very fine gentle rolling carbonation. Fairly soft texture and very easy drinking. Flavor is some crisp hop bite of pine sap and grapefruit rind which rolls to some milder caramel notes in the background. Finish is pretty clean but a lingering hop bite leaves a bitter note across my palate. Also a very drying finish. No hint of any ABV and the beer is very easy to drink. Glad to try this one again, AND finally review this beer. Will remember this one as an option when I want some dry hop bite in a beer.

12 oz can. Packaged in Mills River on June 04, 2021  L: Amber in color, fluffy white head. Noticed (transfixed by) two small streams of bubbles flowing in parallel from the bottom of the glass to the surface. Left a moderate level of lacing. S: Primarily piney resin intertwined with a slight citrus presence. Caramel malt combines with those characteristics to give a nice, pleasant aroma. T: Mostly getting a piney, resinous character giving off a slight bitterness. Perhaps some citrus as a secondary characteristic but it's light to me and seems to give clear deference to the piney resinous aspect. Malt presence is perfect for this beer imo. F: A creamy feel gives way to a slight oily finish. moderate carbonation. O: SNPA is considered a classic for good reason. It's a delicious beer even to this day.

Bottled 5/07  Finally getting around to trying this. First off, this is a beautiful beer. Crystal clear with a big rocky head that leaves lots of sticky lace in its wake. And damned if it isn't tasty as hell! Clean with no off flavors. Prickly citrus rind and a nice lingering tingly pine note. Love the stiff caramel backbone. Very easy to drink too fast. This must have been absolutely revelatory back in the day and it's damn good today.

12oz bottle regular pour into a 120z mug. L: Pours a light amber gold with an off-white medium foamy and lightly creamy head that recedes to thin. Some lacing. Good carbonation. S: Malts, hint of bread, caramel. T: A crisp hop bite then caramel, malt, slight amount of bread yeast. It is not hop forward. The hops deliver some citrus, light melon, pine and some grass. It is semi-sweet. Also tea. The light pine shines through a bit at the finish. F: Medium bodied, lightly rich, smooth feel and has a medium long finish. Lightly sticky or tacky. O: Sierra Nevada Brewing are pioneers in the American craft beer industry. They are tried-and-true. This pale ale is their sound, sailing and seaworthy flagship beer and it's drinkability is amazing. It has a very distinctive caramelized malt characteristic that makes it a bit like candy. It's taste does not change throughout the 12oz drink. It has a stable, poetic and unwavering centralized flavor. Sierra Nevada beers have a stated central, fluid and uniform taste profile. Excellent!

Excellent amber body; very clear; plenty of lively carbonation; thick head, dense and creamy. Enticing smell; pine, citrus, floral; low-key sweet malt notes in the background. Nice, balanced flavors; big pine resin note; fresh orange; light and bright malt taste; mild sweetness throughout; moderate to bold hop bitterness. Medium body; crisp with a mild prickliness on the palate; some stickiness overall yet also has a rather dry mouthfeel throughout.  This is not my first SN pale ale, but it has been years since I last had one. I love the balance between the malt bill and hop bill. One finds some interesting depth and complexity in the beer. At nearly three months of age, this beer is quite enjoyable.  Served at 52 F; bottle label data: PKGD 04/16/21

Sierra Nevada Pale Ale, 5.6% ABV. Pours clear orange with a two finger white head that left some lacing. Nose is citrus, malt, and pine. Taste is citrus and pine, slight sweetness, moderate to heavy bitterness. Excellent mouthfeel, overall excellent.

Pours a deep amber color with a thick cap of off white head. Aroma of citrus peel and pine with a little bit of caramel malt. Slightly sweet caramel note with a bold citrus flavor. Finishes dry with a nice resinous pine bitterness. A flavorful well balanced brew. Medium body with lively carbonation. Overall this is a delicious beer that has stood the test of time. I’m always happy with SNPA in my glass.

Just uncorked immediately citrus notes (especially grapefruit) and pine needles and woody hints and citrus notes (especially grapefruit). When poured, the perfume explodes even more and a caramel note also emerges in the background of the herbaceous ones always predominant. "Deep gold" color. Abundant, soft and tasty foam that does not fade and remains a hat to the beer, therefore excellent persistence. In the mouth, body characterized by the classic smoothness of this beer which, if on the one hand is similar to an English Pale Ale, on the other hand releases hints that are markedly more malty (caramel, biscuit), more fruity (grapefruit, the white orange skin ) and ends with a decidedly more important amaro. The drink is short, refreshing (thanks to a pleasantly lively carbonation), pleasantly tasty and bitter. On the finish and as soon as the beer rests a little in the glass, a final cereal note emerges that tries to rebalance the bitter taste that remains in the mouth. No-frills beer , always at the top in the quality / price / risk ratio (given its constancy over time, at least in my opinion).

SN Pale Ale is one of the first "IPA" I ever drank when I first got into craft beer. At that time I didn't like any IPAs and petty much avoided them completely. I actually didn't like SNPA the first time I had it, but after having a couple more I came to appreciate the balance this beer provides. It was definitely one of the "gateway" "IPAs" that eventually got me to like these hoppier beers. Its funny though, because as the style changes and shifts, I find myself often craving a SNPA as what I really want from an IPA. (And yea, I know its a pale ale, not an IPA, but its easiest to refer to the general category).  This bottle I am drinking today was packaged on 5/21/21. It pours a lovely burnished orange color. Mostly clear, but there are some yeast particulates creating a slight cloudiness. A thick frothy buff head forms on the beer, lingers momentarily, then dissipates leaving just a ring of foam along the outside of the top of the beer. Aroma has light nots of citrus, orange and grapefruit. There is a certain maltiness to the nose, but its quite balanced. Whisps of honey tinge the aroma providing a light sweetness.  Taste has notes of citrus up front - orange and grapefruit - transitioning into some pine and green hop notes. The bitterness is there, but pretty mild - again tit comes across as balanced. Notes of lightly toasted biscuit malts provide the back bone to the beer. Feel is light, smooth and easy drinking. Moderate, but very smooth, carbonation.  Overall this is the classic pale ale. I was drinking this one this morning and kept thinking to myself "why don't I drink this more often?" its better than the vast majority of high priced IPAs I buy. If anything this tasting was a good reminder to me to drink this more often than I do.

It's a good ale, but in my opinion inferior to the Torpedo IPA. I used to drink this regularly. My taste has changed over the years and I like a beer with a fuller body. This is a very good beer, but it is a bit lacking in that area for me now. One good thing about it though is that the alcohol level at 5.6% is a bit better for me than most of the IPAs brewed these days. It is also not overly citrusy tasting.

Added picture you see Part of a variety 24-pack $26.99 Costco 92 days old Smells bready, pine Amber color Medium mouthfeel Medium carbonation Taste of pine, citrus, some bitterness finish. Overall a good beer. I probably would have rated it higher 20 years ago as I remember being much more impressed with it, but now after having had so many craft beers it doesn't wow me as much. Still a solid beer.
Piney, citrusy, hoppy. My favorite APA so far; more to follow.

THE CLASSIC -12 0z. can from 12 pack of dated cans. Mills River version, not that it matters. They match/adjust the water chemistry if needed, and Asheville is a great location for brewing obviously because the water in WNC is good for brewing. Rich honey colored amber ale pours out with a nice head that hangs around awhile, leaves lacing.... Rich aromas of Cascade hops and malts put a smile on my face... Taste is bold and bitter and malty -all together forming a perfect Classic modern pale ale. Feel is smooth and crisp at the same time, spot on for the type. The definitive American Pale Ale, others are good, but this set the hoppy beer world in motion.

12 ounce bottle poured into a Duvel tulip glass. Bottled 5/7/21.  L---Crystal clear Amber color. Fluffy off-white head had good retention, slowly fading down to a cap. OK lacing.  S---Hoppy. Some pine and citrus.  T---Hoppy, pine & citrus.  F---Medium bodied with good carbonation.  O---This was my gateway beer into craft beer back in the 90s. I will always have a soft spot for this one.
Very hoppy and bitter. A really good beer.

12oz bottle. Label has 'PKGD 02/11/21'. Mostly clear, deep gold colored body. One finger of white bubbly head. Leaves rings of lacing. Aroma of lightly toasted malts and citrus/piney hops. Taste is balanced with toasty malt and hops that express pine and citrus (orange and grapefruit). All of this continues into the aftertaste. Bitter and sweet. Medium mouth feel, with just a touch of syrup. Very good carbonation. Classic pale ale that has been the introduction for many to the craft beer world. Yummy good.

Purchased as a six-pack from Exxon for $8.99. Poured into a nonic pint glass.  L - Dark amber with a one-finger cork-colored head. S - Pine tar, cannabis, and an herbal hoppiness is present. Mineral and wheat appear as you let the beer sit a bit. T - White pepper, citrus, and pine. Grassy, herbal notes later come into play on the second sip. Not exactly bitter, but enough hop bite for you to notice it overtake the malt. Barley and bran flakes on the finish. F - Refreshing, clean, full in body. Lightly carbonated. Crisp. O - I've had this beer before, but reviewing this now sort of re-affirms what I already knew: this beer is the quintessential pale ale. I remember when living in WNC, I'd go to a BBQ and always end up seeing several bottles of the stuff. It pairs well with everything, is inoffensive in taste, and isn't filling in the slightest despite its full body. My sole complaint with this beer is that of a common problem with Sierra Nevada beers in general: too hoppy! If the hops were any more overpowering, this brew would easily be an IPA. This being said, the classic Sierra Nevada Pale Ale is an objectively good pale ale, and I'll continue buying this until it stops tasting good with BBQ.

12 oz can (PD02/03/21) poured into a pint glass with a golden/amber color, 1 inch white head and minimal lacing. Smells of citrus, some pine, hops and some malt. The taste follows the aroma with a strong piney hop note, good malt presence and a nice bitterness. Medium body with good carbonation and slightly bitter/dry aftertaste. Overall, one of my all time favorites. A very good hoppy pale ale, almost IPA-like.

Finally after a long long time, I am reviewing this beer! **Looks: Beautiful, pale amber, 2-finger lacing that sticks well to the glass!!! Superb. **Aroma: Mild Cascade hops, mild citrus **Taste: Smooth with mild hoppy punch, this is the definition of Pale Ale. It almost touches being IPA, and draws the clear boundary there. Session beer all the way! Beer kisses. **After-taste: only mild, crispy bitterness that dissipates quickly. ***Overall Verdict*** - Best Pale Beer, it is the standard bearer of Pale Ale in this modern world of increasing IPA, double IPA, triple IPA. Buy it, it is also bottle-conditioned and can-conditioned! Meaning - it stays fresh and smooth longer than traditional IPA’s. What a brewery! What a Beer! CHEERS to a better 2021 & our future years!!!

How can it be that I've never reviewed this classic? At least I can put this in contemporary perspective, with this once outlier brew now being centrist.  Less unusual now than decades ago but the excellent balance and well chosen mix of ingredients still deserve high ratings, particularly for the style.

Look: Clear golden body. Two finger white head has great retention. Smell: Hoppy Taste: This is the first craft beer I ever had. I was in high school and was used to drinking Heineken and Coors Light. I immediately spit out the SNPA because I thought it was too bitter. It’s still bitter, but I like it now! Feel: Thin mouthfeel with medium carbonation. Overall: According to the bottle, this beer sparked the American craft beer revolution. For that, I’m grateful.

Draught pint at The Brass Tap here in Baltimore: Lovely clear copper body, white head that clears quickly with lots of lace & a wispy cap; faint hoppy scent; more piney hops on the tongue; medium body with nice CO2; a very solid IPA - Wait, what? It's a pale ale? An American Pale. Ah, okay then.

Drinking this at home. Poured from a bottle into a pint glass. Looks light amber in color with a nice foamy head that dropped quickly to a thin cap. Smells lightly bready, spicy. Taste follows the nose nicely, more spicy, hoppy like an IPA. Mouth feel is medium for the style. Overall I would definitely drink again. It's a good go to beer when shopping because of its widespread availability. Cheers!

This beer was a huge dissapointment for me..I was thinking that this was going to be one of those class act unique pale ales because of what I've seen in BA but it was hard to drink???  The six pack I picked up was packaged a month out so I thought everything would be good but no-matter how careful I did the 45 degree angle pour followed halfway by the straight pour I got a flat looking, syrupy beer, followed by a weak, limp, Head???  The only taste I got off this brew was sticky, stale, syrupy??? So I imagine I must have gotten possibly a bad batch???  Anyway I wish I could give some highlights off this beer but it's a bust off my first time trying it..I possibly got a bad sixpack, but like I said before the packaged date was only a month out, so I don't understand the sticky, stale caramelized flavor without head???  Unfortunately that's my review? I wish I could have gave more details..

Bought a six pack from Trader Joe's. I had not had this beer for a long time. The packaging had both California and North Carolina listed so I am not sure which one I got. The only difference being the water source and yes that is important. Poured from a 12 oz glass bottle into a 16 oz pint glass. Amber in color with a nice head of foam. I know you're supposed to be able to smell the beer but I never really do. The taste was about like what I remember. A little biscuit, some citrus, a hint of pine needles. It was a little heavy I thought with the mouth feel but par for the course. Over all not bad. In all honesty I prefer something a little lighter but not a light beer. I wish they would tell you exactly which brewery yours was from but it's not a deal breaker. I'd just like to know if the ones I bought was from the Chico brewery or the one in NC. Oh well never mind.
Legend

Look is a very cool amber with a bit of red at the top--it laces nicely as well. Nose is short and dry. Taste is likewise dry. However, it feels a bit too heavy and the finish is mostly just unaccounted for booziness. Overall a decent beer and an excellent choice to get in big pack.

Sierra Nevada Pale Ale SNPA bottle opened at refrigerator temperature and poured into a sham pilsner glass. Foam rose to an inch and a half. The head is white and fairly dense. The body is a healthy amber. The taste is fairly full bodied with a traditional malt and hop character. It's excellent. Interestingly, 30 years ago, when I first encountered SNPA, i thought the taste was lacking in sweet malt body that I craved. Over the years I've become more accepting of the more attenuated flavors in modern craft brews, but I'd still like a little more malty body in my everyday "go to" beer.
wow - an outstanding score, for an outstanding beer. hops, malt, aromas. this beer has it all. californias finest export, when found on the tap, an instant choice - god bless.

Poured from a 12 oz bottle. Had this for the first time in a long time... and after many (hundreds) of other craft beers of both similar and different styles, this is really one of the gold standards for both craft beer, in general, and pale ales, in particular. Great foamy head, great lacing, and nice balance of hoppy bitterness with malted backbone.

If you're on this website, you've had this beer. Not sure a review is necessary, but --  L: Clear, gold / leaning orange S: Lots of cascade; bright, juicy T: Mild, as expected for a pale. Punch of hops up front, fades quickly, very mild bitterness F: Thin, medium carb O: After all these years, still one of the best pale ales on the market

A real granddaddy in the business of craft brews. Even if taste buds have changed in the IPA world, this is still a classic you have to appreciate. A solid, inoffensive beer to bring to a party and even the Bud Light crowd will enjoy.

The king of craft beers, a true original. I’ve been enjoying these almost every day for the past 10 years. They are extremely reliable and an instant relaxation. Taste incredible paired with my favorite foods: Supereme pizza and porterhouse steaks. Enjoy

on tap - this is a very nicely balanced pale ale. It looks a pretty copper, pours with nice white head and tastes great. Mildly fruity with some pine and malt in a gentle mix. It is easy to drink this one. Best to have it on tap.

nice clear amber brew with a bubbly white cap A smell of hops, tropical notes. Great pine notes, citrus and nice malt balance. Not thin mouthfeel, thicker but not medium, great balance. Another nod to a classic beer here.

A solid beer. I tend to dislike highly bitter beers, but this one has a good amount of that doesn't overpower the good hop and malt flavors. It's overall a good one that I'd get in a pinch, but otherwise I'd try some more new things.
Very crushable beer. Not too boozy, which i prefer in my keg. Love it any day of the week.

One of the best if not the best widely available beers you can find in any market. Distribution aside this sets the standard as far as pale ales go. Taste of spicy citrus, pine, and refreshing hops. Has a very crisp feel. Overall, this is awesome and availability is often the best ability at a great price point.
A good beer. Not crazy good.

Pours a dark translucent golden with a white head that sticks around for about two minutes. It smells like biscuity caramel malts with a floral and spicy smell almost like cilantro. There's undertones of lemon orange and pine as it warms up. The taste has a breadier caramel malt flavor but its cut by an immediate spicy citrus line flavor with a nice herbal and slightly bitter finish. It's averagely carbonated and goes down very smoothly. Overall an awesome beer.

Picked-up as part of a mixed twelve pack at Bradford's in Plymouth for about fifteen dollars. I have had this beer many times, did not realize that I had not reviewed it. Haven't had one in a long time, but this is really good, & is a great price point.

L - Golden, pours a nice head. Pretty clear. Could be confused for a stronger lager. S - Pine and citrus but not too strong. Fragrant and sweet aroma. T - Moderately bitter, some of that citrus and pine hops flavor. Hops do not overpower the malt flavor. F - Good mouthfeel, but has kind of a drying feeling in the mouth, kind of astringent. O - A very nice, balanced beer. Has the classic pale ale flavor without being overly bitter or unbalanced. Very easy to find this beer too.

Look: Clear burnt orange leaning red and an all-so-familiar off-white head forms nicely before settling down, leaving good lacing behind Aroma: Citrus notes (orange, lemon, grapefruit), floral hop notes, sweet bready malt, and slight wafts of earthiness Taste: Lemon, grapefruit, and flower petals start of strong and joined by layers of malt and some earthiness. These all blend in seamless harmony before a light hop note (I wouldn’t call it a ‘bite’) and some breadiness finish things out Mouthfeel: Full, smooth, medium-high carbonation, and clean throughout with minimal dryness on the finish Overall: Deliciously balanced and flavorful Pale Ale here and in my opinion, the standard bearer for the style. Cascade hops are fully showcased and a solid and tasty malt bill keep this beer extremely well-balanced. One of a few beers that really led to me getting into the world of microbrew (craft beer) 15 years ago and it still is a stellar beer

Update: 7/7 An excellent robust off-white head forms, retained well later. Big and bubbly. Much carbonation is seen in a light caramel liquid with red hue. Cloudy but not hazy, and rather thin. The nose borders an amber but way hoppier and lighter biscuit notes. There is a malt sweetness of caramel. A definite sharpness on the tongue tip and a blast of hops, wonderfully washed away by even maltiness. Extreme on both ends yet easy drinking. Hop burn is leftover in the mouth with a spiciness.

Deep gold, white head, excellent retention and lace Floral, grapefruit and pine hop aromas, a bit of caramel malt underneath Nice grapefruit hop flavor on a solid caramel malt backbone Medium bodied, clean, and properly carbonated. A classic for a reason

Taste/Price this is like the beer. I know people out there who aren't crazy about this beer, and I wish I didn't know them. Their opinions are bad, and they are bad people. Sierra Nevada, for good people.

Classic go to pale ale. Poured Cold from the bottle, amber-gold, sparkling with tiny bubbles and a healthy white head. Refreshing malt-hoppy aroma and pine. Classic pale ale taste, crisp with a full-bodied mouth feel. This is a refreshing, delicious, easy drinking pale ale!

Info: PCKGD 2/3/2020, 12 oz. glass bottle, served 50*F in a pint glass at sea level  L: Brilliant amber-gold. Clean, white head. Moderately persistent (5 mins.) S: Toasted malt, resin, sweet citrus, melon. T: Rounded malt, light bitterness, salt, sodabread, pine, melon. F: Wet, medium body, lightly warming.  O: Tastes like the label looks. Don't know if it's just because of the packaging, but it just tastes "green" to me, as if someone juiced a pine forest. Refreshing, well-rounded: enjoyable!

Last time I was in California, I was, admittedly, a fetus. But, just because I have not experienced California physically, does not mean I haven’t done so spiritually: People fail to recognize that The Golden State is so much more than beaches and Hollywood. It is pine, it is Earth, it is rustic, it is mountainous, and it is eye-opening. Such is the experience elucidated from the Sierra Nevada Pale. It pours a beautiful amber reflecting the Somerville sky, and at 5.6%, I was just about ready to head over to Encore and gamble away my tuition after a few of em. Highly recommend!

A California classic, saw it on menus many years before I could drink it, once I could it has been enjoyed in bottles and on tap all over the state. L: A hop green label with a mountain/hop/wheat painting, pours golden with sturdy head if you want S: Hoppy, boozy T: No frills pale ale, you get what you expect, the colder the smoother, nice balance between the hops, wheatyness and booziness. Delicious fresh on tap, but reliable in the bottle (to a point with age) F: Bready, hoppy, sweeter as it warms. O: A delicious classic.

L - Frothy, golden, see-through, with enough lacing and head for enjoying several minutes worth. S - Great pine, citrus, forest floor scents, and some good malt whiff in balance here. T - Classic light-bitter and forest malt tastes here, still the one. F - Great mouthfeel, balance, never out of whack and USUALLY fresh at local stores. Has the same palate impact of old school IPAs back in the day, but with a brightness the latter could not match. O - still a great drinking pale ale, after all these years.

Bottled 3/23/20 Consumed 8/11/20  This isn't exactly peak freshness, but is a pretty good example of what generally happens when I'm in a hurry at the build-your-own-six-pack cooler. Out-of-date IPAs end up in my possession. Clear golden honey body with a fingers worth of head that quickly fades to a ribbon. Smells clean and grainy with some bitter hops mixed in. Tastes fairly bitter too, but it's well balanced with the malt. Clean, lager-esque finish. I need to return to this when I get my hands on a fresher sample and have more time for an in-depth review.

Pours a clear, copper color with an inch thick white head that dissipated in about a minute, high amount of carbonation. The smell is sweet, malts up front. The taste is very balanced between malts and hops, bread notes up front followed by a piney hop bitterness. This beer is very crisp, clean on the mouthfeel. It’s light bodied and highly drinkable, yet it’s got a lot of flavor. Overall, great job from one of the country’s original craft breweries. Classic beer that doesn’t get old, and one I like to come back to when I get tired of over the top big beers.

I've had this many times, but never as a side by side with the other coast's storied Pale Ale, Hill Farmstead Edward, which many know as having taken its inspiration from SNPA. Actually having the opportunity to do this head to head with Hill finally canning Edward is a blessing in the middle of a pandemic, but finding that it only elevated both beers in unique ways was even more pleasant of a surprise, so I couldn't help but completely delete and redo my old review of this reliable standby, as the comparisons and contrasts are very enjoyable to take note of.  While Edward is a hazy, nearly fully opaque pale amber-orange with a moderate, creamy khaki head, SNPA is sparkling clear darker amber with a slightly taller, slightly darker khaki foam head that collapses under large airy bubbles.  The similarities are present, yes. Edward is a little more bitter and a little more maltier than most of Hill's hoppy brews, or many other NEPAs/IPAs, which is in line with elements of SNPA, itself further diverging by being toastier and adding very mild notes of caramel and pine resinous aftershave.  However, the differences are stark. Drastically stark.  Edward is creamier, fuller, and juicier. It almost has a vanilla cream quality by comparison, with that Hill yeast and shortbread-like malt combination. It even has a hint of that bubblegum character to it that I always get in Tree House brews, and rarely get elsewhere, which is the biggest surprise to me here.  Either way, none of that takes away from SNPA, which is a high quality beer that's immensely crushable for a relatively bitter ale with a respectable complexity and insane shelf life. It may even be the preferred option for some, such as my old lady, who enjoyed SNPA more for it's drinkability in this head to head. With that in mind, Edward does feel heavier, but it's so delicious I wouldn't change a thing about it either. SNPA's signature but measured and crisp West Coast bitterness clearly sets it apart, and its reliability for when you need a quality "beer flavored beer" that has that nice mild bite to it is unmatched.

This beer pours a beautiful opaque amber color that has a glow to it, tops off with a nice 1/2 inch white head. Picking up a lot of floral, earthy & pine notes in the aroma. Taste pretty much follows the nose, the bitterness of this beer is very balanced. Medium carbonation with a raw feeling to it. Can't go wrong with this classic beer, it's widely available & easily crushable.

Colour is amber/orange with a cream head that fades but leaves a ring of froth throughout. Aroma is quite floral and earthy. The taste is of burnt quite sweet malts and a piney hop taste that is pleasant and not overpowering. Medium bodied. Mouthfeel is a lingering sweet and bitter with some carbonation on the palate.  Has a piney kick that gives it character yet it's reigned in by some sweetness in the malts to balance things out. Really smooth, balanced and tasty. It's probably not at its freshest by the time it gets to this country but it's still very good.

12oz bottle, dated 05.06.2020, poured into a stemless wine glass.  The beer pours a very nice amber color, copper and orange hues, slight chill haze and some bubbles racing around the beer with about a finger and a half of white frothy head that has good retention and excellent lacing. The aroma is very nice, pine, orange peel, grapefruit juice, a bit grassy with a nice assertive amber malt character. The flavors are good, strong grains lead the way, pale dough and amber cereal grains with a nice crisp grapefruit character, some soft floral and fruitiness comes out before the bitter pine and grapefruit peel start to take over, earthy and grassy at the finish. The mouthfeel is very good, coating with a lively medium body that finishes with a crisp and dry bite.  Verdict: The quintessential west coast style pale ale. After years of experimentation and evolution within the industry, this might seem boring or pedestrian but it's certainly one of the most sessionable and flavorful pale ales and there is good reason why this is the standard to which so many beers get compared.
Only thing I can say about this one is if your buying beer from a gas station more than likely this will be the best one you can find in the cooler. The OG craft beer.

Sierra Nevada's head has a great look with tons of lasting foam. I can tell this is an incredibly made beer but the taste specifically didn't seem all there. I have to try this beer again because maybe I just tasted less than perfect batch.

L - Beautiful dark gold almost copper, looks appetizing. Moderate carbonation that pours to a 3 finger head that quickly dissipates to a thin cap with a thicker ring. Light lacing  S - Citrus, Peach and some Berries. Like some mix fruit juices in our ref!  T - Follows the nose. Refreshing citrus, herns, and bitter hops up front, but as stated by a reviewer, balanced by sweet bready malt and a light toast that follows and lingers.  F - Bold but refreshing and easy. Moderate carbonation gives a crisp feel that lightens an otherwise filling drink. Warm of the alcohol all through the drink  O - my first craft beer and now i finally see what they are all about. Honestly i may not appreciate a grocery pilsner anymore after this. Such a welcome complex drink. Watch the alcohol it is there.

This beer hails from my home town so I am probably biased but its a good beer if you like ales. Slightly sour tasting but not heavy or too filling. Easy to drink on those hot summer days that Chico, CA is renown for. Beware that the alcohol can sneak up on you though if you have more then a couple in one sitting.

L- Very clear burnt orange color. with a big white head that dissipates quickly. It has some pretty visible legs. S- Can pick up some mild earthy hop aroma and can smell a faint sweet and citrusy aroma as well. T- Initially taste the pale malt sweetness with an ever so slight roasted taste as well. Then there is the hop presence that brings a light citrus note with some earthy bitterness left in the mouth. F-Nice medium bodied and light prickliness from the carbonation. O- A solid pale ale that doesn't go overboard with the hops. It lets the malt be present but also lets there be a pleasant hop taste. Its also at a good price point which is great.

This is my style of choice for summer days. Only recently have I tried this brew. I love it for all of the reasons that it is ranked "outstanding" on this forum.  I remember the dark days of macro-brewery dominance. I cannot believe that one time in my life I'd have expressed the same appreciation for Budweiser. On special occasion a skunky green bottled import like Heineken or Becks.  I was screwed out of a proper childhood in NYC without a decent local brew!

Deep golden orange with strong head. Aroma of fresh cut grass, pine needles, and lemon. Sweet candy like lemon flavor, like a lemon loaf cake, warms and develops into grapefruit rind bitterness. Fresh refreshing and balanced. Feel is sturdy with moderate bubbles.  It really is such a well done beer. If I had only one particular beer to drink for rest of life I'd be happy with this.
The craft beer that started it all for me 25 yrs ago. Still an lovely balance of Cascade hops and caramel malt. Perfect melding of the two with a bite at the end that has stood the test of time

I got a very fresh 12 pack of this packaged in the retro 12 pack, an homage to the original 1980 release with a color gradient that was the result of a printing error for their first batch of this legendary brew. Poured into my Samuel Smith pint glass, paired with Rotisserie chicken and potato salad.  Look: Absolutely brilliantly clear amber that has a hearty slightly off-white head with great retention. A solid, half-pinky thick cap leaves light lacing. The clear body shows moderate carbonation, steadily rising to fuel the aromatic head. This beer looks amazing in the glass.  Smell: The aroma is a perfect blend of biscuity malt that jumps right out of the glass with a nice backing of pine, citrus, grassy, floral, and herbal hops. The Two-row Pale and Caramelized malts hugely contribute to the aroma. I also detect honeysuckle, toasted cracker, and clean barley.  Taste/Feel: A delicious wave of caramel malt washes across the palate, simultaneously balanced by pine, citrus, and herbal hop character. Both citral and botanical, the Cascade hop shines here lending refreshingly zesty bitterness that perfectly compliments the toasty malt profile. I found the botanical properties to give an almost spicy impression, similar to Saaz hops. The body is very smooth. Slight astringency on the mid-palate. The finish is dry and lingers flavors of tea leaves, granny smith apple skin, cracked grain, lemon peel, clover honey, and a mild nuttiness. Very balanced and drinkable.  Overall: It's easy to see why this beer is the best selling pale ale in the country. It's very clean, drinkable, and enjoyable. I love how they single-hopped it with Cascade hops, it's a great way to experience what that hop has to offer. Also, these were very fresh so if yours is even a month old you will likely miss out on a lot of the hop flavors so will not detect any slight spiciness.

Bottle with retro artwork, bottled 05 Mar. Been forever since I've had one.  A gorgeous copper with a dense, off-white head with excellent retention and exceptional lacing. The nose is excellent. Bright, sharp grapefruit, candied orange, a touch of pine, all tempered by a delicate caramel sweetness. The palate opens moderately bitter with the classic Cascade hop flavor, but without much of the chalkiness I remember. Clean, bright, moderately pungent with orange, grapefruit, a little pine, a delicate sweetness with a light caramel and honey note. The mid palate is dominated by the sweeter flavors duking it out with the bitterness. Let's call it a tie. Drying, bitter, clean and vibrant on the finish, the mouthfeel is initially a little thin and overcarbonated but once it dies down, this is a pleasure. Quite excellent, truly a classic.

*Poured into a Teku glass from a 12oz bottle at 50F*  Poured a nice clear amber look into my glass, reminiscent of apple cider. Had a nice finger-half thick head with an off white creamy color to it and a nice retention. Very satisfying to look at, no complains here what-so-ever.  The aroma of this was super balanced between the malt and the hops. I got a nice mellow malty smell reminiscent of Hawaiian rolls and caramel--this was balanced out with some of the esters of the hops, smelling of over-ripe red apples and a slightly vague citrus aroma. If I could pinpoint this aroma combination to something specific, I would say it would be of caramel apples.  As for the taste, it was fairly malt-forward, but it wasn't overwhelmingly so. Towards the middle, I was able to taste more of the fruity apple characteristics that I got from the aroma. Towards the end, I was able to pick up on its more citrus-y grapefruit bitterness--very subtle, not lingering or overwhelming.  The feel of this beer was satisfying and made the beer super drinkable. It was medium bodied with a light-medium carbonation, the best way I can describe the feel of this beer is very clean and very crisp, not to mention refreshing.  Overall, I really liked this beer. I feel like this is a very balanced and well rounded beer that could be paired with almost anything with a meat dish. Would definitely drink this again in my next barbecue gathering or with some crispy fried chicken with some friends!

L - Golden amber, cream head, and a bit unfiltered. S - Earthy floral, citrus, and pine hop smell. T - Moderately sweet, somewhat bready malt balance out the hops. F - Medium body and fairly carbonated.  Quite tasty. I was pleasantly surprised--Not that I expected it to be bad, but I don't drink as many hop-forward beers as I used to and hadn't had one in a while.
fluffy, off-white head that sticks around, amber body, clear  sweet, citrus, caramel, grass? sulfur? dusty?  bitter, juicy, malt at the back end, medium bodied

This one was a little disappointing considering how popular it is. I expected a little more from this great brand. No date printed on bottle. Pours a slightly medium darker golden color with a little fluffy white head and some spotty lingering lacing that lasted for a while. Smells of muddled fruity and floral hops, caramel, weaker malt, vanilla, bread and maybe a touch of herbal hops at the finish. Taste follows the nose, ok balance but I wish there were more depth and complexity. Also seemed to lack a decent hoppy bitter bite. Smooth, mild mouthfeel with fairly good carbonation. I wish I knew how old this beer was and it did seem that it could’ve used a little more strength in its hoppiness.

First things first...this is definitely the beer that kicked all of this shit off for me...the trailblazer that I first tried in 1992!!  Look...clear but a darker brown than the pales of today. nice foam. a little lacing Smell...hint of citrus earthy, hoppy smell (duh). Taste...up front tingly dry citrus, bitter back end, smooth finish. Game changing taste at the time and still really nice crisp. Overall...this is what any pale ale should aspire to. Very drinkable...Classic!!
This is how it's done! Classic craft American pale ale. Enjoy!
A standard for sure. Balanced, enough hop, enough aroma, good reference on which to judge the others.

I finally bought 2 cans at the lcbo of this awesome pale ale poured into my glass with a beautiful 2 to 3 finger head the smell of the beer was more citrus then the taste. Very enjoyable and refreshing to drink . Taste is amazing its gotta be the special hops in this beer that makes it so good and yes I would buy this beer again. Cheers

My first “craft beer”. The one that started it all and got me into craft beer. It tastes really good. And is recommended to anyone who is starting to venture out of the darkness of watered down crappy beer and into the light of flavorful beer. It holds up pretty good ten years later of a full on craft beer exploration. Love torpedo too!

Look: The colour of amber, generous fluffy white foam head, 2 fingers.  Smell: All citrus and pine  Taste: Crisp and fresh. Pine, lavender and a sweet bitterness.  Feel: Rich and smooth, rides up high on your palate.  Overall: I've never been a hop head kind of guy, in fact IMHO a lot of well regarded craft beers rely on overwhelming the taster with their hops to their detriment. This beer hits the sweet spot with my palate. The hops are well balanced, firm but gentle enough to be enjoyable. This beer earns a solid B+

This is a popular beer. I have not had this in years, so grabbed one in a City Market sampler pack. It does have bitter, and nalt taste. But I can't taste any pine, or refreshing citrus to it. West Coast IPAs and the newest trend NE "juicy hazy" IPA are quite more my taste preference. First beer I had today was An Avery Pacer hazy IPA which is as light and delicious as can be.

Look: Crystal clear amber color with tons of fine bubbled foamy head. Nothing lacking in the lacing department. Not a lot of visible carbonation, might be my current lighting. Smell: Aroma reminds me of a German pilsner, and to me, that is a compliment. Taste: No sweetness on the tip of the tongue, biter from front to back, bitter on the back of the tongue. Flavor: It tastes like a European beer taking it’s first step toward what becomes the style now know as American IPA. It tastes like history in a glass. I am sooooo glad that Sierra Nevada has continued brewing this from 1980 until now. Feel: Full mouthfeel, light carbonation dry finish Overall: This is such a landmark beer! If you are old and remember how the American beer scene changed from the 70’s to the 80’s, you should drink this beer in remembrance. If you are too young to remember I recommend drinking an American Adjunct Lager, then Sierra Nevada Pale Ale and finally the IPA of your choice. If your drink carefully you will receive revelation from the beer gods of what they intended by calling men like Ken Grossman (founder of Sierra Nevada) into their service. It is a sublime experience! I have given it an overall score that is higher than any of the component scores because of it's place in the history of American brewed beer. This and Anchor Steam changed EVERYTHING!!! Thanks Ken! When you drink this you can experience what Ken Grossman and Fritz Maytag discovered with the Cascade hops, the hops that changed, yes, EVERYTHING! I was in Europe in 1980 and I felt embarrassed by the beer that was produced in the USA. Now, obviously American beer is deservedly respected across the pond and we American owe a debt of gratitude to Ken and Fritz!

The look was good and the smell was even better. This was the first IPA I ever tried. The notes of citrus and pine are what make this beer an average beer. To me, it didn't taste like it came together. It seemed like a mixture of flavors that kind of clashed with one another.
One of my top favorite 3 beers and my first introduction to a beer with a hop foward flavor.

L- Mid to dark amber, clear. Pours with 1Cm pillowy white head (holds very well). S- Hmm, apart from a 'beer' fragrance I don't get anything specific or distinctive from it at all - a bit of a surprise. T- It's a grown up APA. It has moderate dry hopping but is not OTT as some comtemporary iterations of the style can be. Neither does it use hops that bring in bonkers (to me) lychee, mango or other out of place fruit facets. F- It has some meatiness to it, some decent presence. O- It's pretty good, drinkable and sessionable. But it's not that distinct or full of character (IMO) to warrant the ratings it seems to attract. Maybe it works better in the US at US prices, vs US competition vs abroad where it's a $-premium import facing different competition? Bought from WholeFoods, London W8. £1.80/355ml bottle.

Six pack of bottles picked up at Total Wine in Lynnwood, Washington. Served in a mason jar a couple at a time.  Look- Clear golden amber color. Modest fluffy white head that recedes slowly to a thin cap, spotty lacing. Moderate carbonation streams visible.  Smell- Citrus (grapefruit and lemon), resinous pine, caramel malt and floral/herbal notes.  Taste- Much like the nose, pithy citrus with a piney and malty follow through, pretty nicely balanced.  Feel- Medium bodied, dry and crisp with a lingering moderately bitter finish. Medium carbonation on the tongue.  O- What can you say? Basic and really easy drinking. One of the quintessential classics that set an early benchmark for where craft brewing has come to today.

Oh hello, old friend! How I have missed you, in search of that perfect beer and you’ve been here all along. You take me back with open arms, without judgement.  It’s hard to believe that at one time I couldn’t drink this beer as it was too heavy, too bitter. Crushing all of those keystone lights in high school skewed my tastes just a little...Hard to imagine that this is the easy drinking beer now.  But the difference is the flavor! How much flavor! In my search of the ever stronger, ever more bitter, I’ve come full circle to this old reliable to realize what a perfect beer. Light, but full of flavor. Not trying to be something that it’s not trying to be, like an IPA that tries to go all day. Oh hey, have some pale ales in a session instead. Beautiful amber, which some champagne bubbles. Super fresh, no bottle conditioned sediment. Clear, amber, and crisp. Light ever present frothy head. Apricot and malt. Floral lavender and caramel. Light, not overly heavy, but good strong mouthfeel. Great beer. Classic beer. Staple in my refrigerator beer.

12oz bottle  Pours two big fingers of fluffy, pillowy white head into my Boston Lager glass. Retention is still immaculate after a few minutes. Body is full of bubbles and is a dark orange with hints of yellow. High clarity. Looks great so far.  Nose is bready, caramel, subtle notes of citrus and pine. Pretty distinguishable aromas. Somewhat straight forward, but hey it’s a pale. Smells good, as it always does.  Flavor is maybe a touch of pine, not any citrus, malts are pretty muted as well. As with the last Sierra Nevada, somewhat flavorless. Still carbonated at the time the of first sip, and using a different glass, so maybe their quality has just gone down. Nothing bad, just boring.  Carbonation is holding at about medium, though I’m trying to drink it somewhat quickly in leu of all the nucleation. Body is definitely on the lighter side. Pretty damn dry, hops balance it out well in that regard, though there is not a lot of maltiness to begin with. Bitterness is surprisingly noticeable considering how little flavor there is, yay early hop additions. Good mouthfeel, dryness is a little much at times though, and could be a tad more refreshing.  Drinkability is high, that’s not the issue here.  Appearance turned out wonderful, retention was wonderful and lacing was thick.  Overall, idk, I regard this beer as a very good go to, but this is perplexing. The last SN was creeping up on flat and that effected a lot of things, not so much here. In this case it could simply be that I’m used to a newer style of pale and IPA, this is probably more old school now that I take a second to think about it, so is it inherently worse? Probably not to everyone, but I want more flavor.

Gold with 1 finger head. Nose is medium light grapefruit and pine with bready malt background. Flavor is fairly grassy with a sort of honey or maple malt sweetness, moderately bitter. Light mouthfeel.
Not much to say except Sierra’s Pale Ale is an outstanding beer. It poured a 1/4 inch head, had a honey color and had little to no aroma. Taste is near perfect.

Not exactly mind blowing. But it's pleasant to drink. Pours small head with reddish orange color. Smells rather light, not very hoppy, just like regular beer. Tastes like a pale ale, pretty basic hoppy flavors. Doesn't waste you, relatively refreshing and should appeal to the people who can't stand really heavy IPAs.

Poured from a can.  Look Light gold with a thick white foam. It has great head retention and moderate lacing. Smell starts with citrus, then grapefruit, and finishes with pine. Taste is well balanced, follows the nose with the addition of moderate bitterness finishing with maltiness. Feel has a smooth and almost creamy texture that is most noticeable on the swallow. The mouth feel is amazing for a pale ale. Overall it is a high quality beer that is very satisfying.
Excellent 'light' IPA at 5.6% ABV. Smooth and easy to drink - especially for light weights that are moving up from any of the standard commercial pisswater beers.
11/2019 bottle 01/2020 12 pack from Sam’s

L: Nice golden colour, very slightly hazy, pretty lacing, three finger initial head S: Pineiness, nuttiness, grapefruit, jam, hint of orange and lemon T: Lots of grapefruit, sweet hops, something resembling watermelon at the back F: Quite well-bodied, refreshing on the palate  O: 4.25

I always believe my next beer will be my best therefore i have not drank a SNPA until last night. I always enjoy this Pale Ale but I don't remember this amount of malt taste in it. Still one of the best around. Thank you Sierra Nevada for making great beer.
Way tooooo Hoppy..Looking for a unpasteurized citrus cask ale taste
11/9/19 - Single from Elkton; did a comparison with Monument City Pagoda (pale ale). Both are very nice. Monument is a bit sharper compared to the milder SNPA, but very nice as well.

An exceptional pale ale by any standard. Golden amber in colour, pours well with nice head. Really enjoyable citrus aroma and flavour that lingers but isn't bitter at the end like others I've tried. Smooth and drinkable. Overall one of my favourites.

Pours golden with a 1/2 inch white head. Moderate lacing as you go.  Aroma is grapefruity, piney, resiny, grassy.  Tastes of strong pine and grapefruit. Good bitterness.  Medium bodied, dry mouthfeel. Light carbonation.  While this is a good IPA, it's not the best in the class.

Citrusy floral and hop forward. Heavy on the pine scent but the maltiness can be overpowering. As Pale ale is concerned this is a good flagship beer.  Poured from the bottle into a standard beer mug. Not at ice cold temp. Two finger slow dissipating head. Only mild lacing on the glass.

To me this is the pale ale I judge all others against. It’s not the best, but it’s damn good. Huge plus that you can walk into almost any beer store and find it. Hoppy up front, earthy on the back end. Very drinkable. A classic

The beer is a nice pale amber color with a frothy head that sticks around a good for a paler beer. The smell is muted but enticing. You can smell the hops and some sweetness. Tasting it, the flavor is very present. The malt and hops were very well together. The beer is crisp with a good amount of complexity to it. The hops are citrusy and piney with. It is not very bitter but bitterness is there, especially in the after taste. The mouthfeel is really nice. It foamy and somewhat soft. Overall, a very crushable beer.
Finally getting around to trying this one. Happy hour at Pies and Pints in Morgantown after the skin doctor. On tap. Those one pretty much hits all the right characteristics of an APA.

The Sierra Nevada Pale Ale is the BEST “standard ale” for taste, appearance and feel. It’s hard to believe it’s a “daily beer” for the amazing quality of taste and aroma and texture. No beer can touch this one for a daily drink ale. The Sierra Nevada hoppier ales (like the Little Hazy Thing and Celebration Ale) kick it up a notch with more highlights, but are truly a more “special brew” style not a daily brew to enjoy. My personal favorite for an ALWAYS tasty brew year round!

From the back label of the bottle: "PKGD 07/22/19 1708"  Appearance: The body is a light gold color with good clarity. The head is thick, white, and frothy. It has perfect head formation, retention, and lacing.  Aroma: There is a light lemon zest aroma with a touch of lime.  Taste: The beer has a noticeable lime flavor with a bit of pine in the back and just a hint of alcohol. Lemon comes through in the aftertaste and lingers around for a while. The flavors in the beer definitely make one sit up and take notice.  Mouthfeel: It is a very refreshing beer with a lighter body and a pleasant effervescence. It is a very enjoyable beer to drink.  Overall: Simply put, this beer is tasty and enjoyable. This is a very multi-purpose beer when it comes to food recommendations, where it would pair with anything from a hamburger to a cheese tray. The bottle seems to have held up very nicely flavor-wise for being just under three months old, so I would definitely recommend it within that timeframe or sooner. I would drink it again but I would like to try it on tap or from a can. It's a very enjoyable beer.

It pours an amber body with a little bit of visible carbonation. There's also a lot of tiny floaties. It has a medium, soapy, off-white head with little lacing.  The aroma has grassy hops, grapefruit, floral and honey.  The taste has sweet malts, pine, grass and grapefruit. The finish is dry, with a lingering grapefruity bitterness to it. The mouthfeel is medium bodied, with medium bitterness and light sweetness.  A smooth, well balanced pale ale.

This beer took me a while to warm up to. I used to think it was too hoppy but I gradually grew to appreciate hops more and started to enjoy this. I still don't like IPAs and tend to prefer British style ales but every once in a while I find myself in the mood for an APA and this really hits the spot.

This beer is fukn awesome. I have had 1,000+ IPAs, lots of Pale Ales and this pale ale is my go-to in the best stocked liquor store one could find. Just an absolute dream boat of a simplistic classic. Head is great, smells like malty greatness and hops and tastes crisp but complex in a simple, straightforward kind of way. Finish is on point

From old, undated notes. Poured from the can.  Murky light yellow color.  Foamy white head; strong lacing.  Light hops in the nose, malts also present.  Light mouthfeel.  Taste is slightly lager-ish, malty & not much hops.  I'd slam one on a hot day but I won't be reaching for another anytime soon.

I was very curious how this famous beer it taste and was little exciting before drink it.. Also it has one awesome label outside and your imagination flying. Anyway the aroma remind me a lot the "Belgium Pauwel Kwak" beer and also little the colour.. The taste was something between "Lager" and some "Belgium" beer in the aftertaste.. The first mouthfeel was slightly bitter and remind you a lot "Lager" beers and the aftertaste was very malty and remind some "Belgium" beers like "Leffe Blond" and "Pauwel kwak".. This combination little trouble me but definitely i enjoy that beer despite is not my style.. I like more sweet beers and less bitter.. Overall a very refreshing and good all around beer to drink but can't touch the stadards of some "Belgium" and "German" beers out there..

I was a late bloomer as far as drinking IPAs and Pale Ales. My son would bring home growlers of hoppy craft brews when he was college and I soon learned to enjoy them. About 2 years ago I tried Sierra Nevada. Now its my go to pale ale. It pours dark orange brown, has a thick white head with lacing. Has a slightly heavy mouth feel with lots of balanced hop flavor. Finish is clean, pleasant. 12 packs are competitively priced. So for me, this is about as good as it can get.

L: golden amber with light head and lace S: piney hops with a touch of resin T: upfront hops with spicy backend F: much stronger up front presentation and mellows out on backend O: a good quality ale that holds its own

Pours golden amber with nice lacing white cap. Notes of spicy fragrant hops, pine and bread. Good taste and balance of hops and malt. GoTo standard for America’s pale ale.  Revisited this after so many other “more complex flavored” IPA’s and now have a better appreciation for this classic great!

alien code/no date? pint Can, poured into IPA glass. How can they not just date cans? Perfect deep golden clear body, big head, lacing around sides Briefly sweet, biting piney/citrus hop flavor, malt fullness underneath - nice cut, very decent for sure, hence the pint. Feel is right there , crisp and clean, almost an outdoor experience in itself. Good enough to have once in awhile, but there are others I prefer over this most times for some reason.  *eidted Jun/2020: It's better every time I get it.
A great balance of maltiness and hops. Smooth and easy drinking.

Poured from a bottle into a standard tap glass.  Pours nearly crystal clear bronze with an outstanding foamy head, great retention and excellent lacing.  Malts, hops, and grains all swirl around the nose in well-balanced and equal measures.  The brew hits the tongue with a slightly sweet and spicy malt flavor. The mid-palate enjoys spicy grainy yeast. The finish is a nice, earthy dry hop note. Overall, a well-balanced, restrained flavor.  The feel is medium-light to medium, with excellent carbonation and a nice drying finish.  This was one of the first craft beers I ever tried, many years ago. This is the first time I've had one in 10 years. It still stands up. APA's can be "shy" on flavor. Not this classic. It may lack some of the nuance of more recent offerings, but this is one of the most well-balanced brews I've had.

Pours to a pale amber color with a light head. Aroma is light and contains pine snd citrus notes.  The flavor is of grass and spice with a crisp after taste.  Sierra Nevada is a famtastic brewery and this is currently my favorite American Pale Ale.

12oz bottle - dated 03/05/19 - poured into a Spiegelau-style IPA glass at 45F  Pours a bright copper hue, nearly crystal clear, with about two fingers of very off white head, which possesses impressive retention, never fully dissipating to less than a full cap, and leaving a perfect ring of clingy lace behind.
