Fine ascending streams of effervescence are visible.  Nose: A hefty base of caramel malt is apparent on the nose. Slightly sweet, slightly toasty, crisp, and warm. Among the malt, a generous dose of Cascade hops waft up, with aromas of grapefruit, lemon, pine resin, pear, and perhaps even a note of sweet ripe mango. There is no earthiness, but rather a green element to the nose that evokes images of a forest. Lots of floral notes as well, including lilac, hyacinth, and Easter lilly.  Palate: Like the nose, the first sip unfolds with caramel malt. Semi-sweet, slightly toasty, and crisp, with notes of caramel, fresh bread, and toffee. Hops cut in rather late, bringing mostly pine sap, spring florals, cedar, and some citrus character. There is less of a grapefruit note than one might imagine with a beer like this. Cascade hops are not like Citra. They are piney, resinous, and sort of "woodsy". In fact, I would say the citrus notes in this beer are far closer to lemon than grapefruit. Only upon swallowing do the hops really overtake the malt, with a gentle bitterness showing up in the finish, amd the flavour profile becoming drier and more resinous. Still, well after the finish, the aforementioned caramel malt sweetness is still detectable in small doses around the palate.  Mouthfeel/Body: The beer is medium bodied, crisp in nature, but the caramel malt provides a soft, slick, slightly chewy feel to it. For a pale ale, it certainly has some respectable weight to it, and a really employable softness. Effervescence is lively and plentiful, and also incredibly fine, almost champagne-like. Still, while the beer is crisp and drinkable, and although it has a fairly low ABV, I don't think I would want to drink more than 24oz in one sitting. This is one where the weight of the malt may creep up on you.  Overall: Sierra Nevada Pale Ale is a classic. It's an old school, West Coast staple. Each of us have most likely consumed gallons of this stuff by this point, and there is a very good reason for that. It is a stellar beer. It's a no-frills, simple, easy, highly polished hoppy ale that does not demand one's attention with complexity, while remaining incredibly flavour-saturated, and never boring. It is a perfect default beer that most can agree on. It's affordable, it's tasty, it's incredibly consistent, and the quality is top notch. It won't win any awards for exotic hops or complex tropical fruit notes, but it does everything you want it to do and more, and for that, it really is one of the greatest pale ales on the market.

Look: Clear amber-brown with a persistent tan-white head. Smell: Lemon and grapefruit citrus. Hints of pine and malt. Taste: Grapefruit citrus mixed with malt sweetness. Hint of raspberry. Slightly peppery/spicy hop finish. Feel: Medium-bodied with crisp carbonation. Overall: This is a solid beer with some really interesting flavors going on.

Bottle to shaker pint. Golden yellow with about an inch of head that dissipates by over half within a minute. Very nice fragrance of hops and slight citrus. Very pleasant and balanced flavor with a slight malty sweetness. Feel is smooth with the slightest of tang and bitterness. Not a huge ale fan but I do like this one.
One of my "go tos" but there are so many great beers out there today this is kindsa my "bud lite". Being from CA I had to stop by SN - MR while in NC. Heading to my fav Wilmington...

A normal amber color, no head but ample carbonation. Terrific aroma. Great hop smell. The taste is excellent and very hoppy. Mouthfeel is only slightly bitter and compliments the taste in this pale ale. Overall an excellent choice for Pale Ales when you’re in the mood.

473 mL Bottle. ABV 5.6%. Appearance: Clear golden/orange, Low carbonation, Over one finger of loose and fluffy off-white head, Thin cap remains. Aroma: Lemon, Pine, Slight tropical fruit, Hops Mouthfeel: Under medium body, Pleasant carbonation, Pleasant bitter finish. Flavour: Malt sweetness, Citrus fruits (orange and grapefruit), Medium hoppy finish. Overall: Clean, Well balanced, Quite enjoyable.  Review: 30
Super refreshing pale ale. A classic beer.

Bottled on 3/5/19  Pours a clear golden orange-copper topped with a few fingers of tightly-composed white foam; great retention that trickles its way down to a thick, frothy cap while leaving layers of webby lacing following to the bottom of the glass.  Aroma hits with smooth, semi-sweet caramel malt upfront, eventually giving way to deep pine, herbal hops, red grapefruit, and orange zest developing in that order; a potent and drying bouquet.  Taste shows crisp caramel malts balanced with sharp piney hops and a touch of citrusy grapefruit on the back end; hints of wild berries develop fervently around/on the swallow.  Mouthfeel has a light, crisp body reinforced with fluffy, drying carbonation; brief heft on the mid-palate serves only to guide this one to a new height, an immensely satisfying dryness tinged with a faint, bitter hoppiness; for a pale ale, this is about as good as it gets.  A seminal pale ale for a reason, it holds up with its incredible malt-hop harmony and dynamic simplicity; it does alot without ever abandoning its easy-drinking nature. An effortless beer for all occasions.

Poured from a 12 ounce bottle into a shaker pint.  Look - A healthy clear golden amber body with a powerful soft white head. Bubble streams are minimal. The head sticks around for a while before diminishing into a hefty lace.  Smell - Grapefruit and a breezy pine air out of this one. Gentle and caring, this smell lures you into its safe nest.  Taste - Immediately noticeable is the sweet and mild malty backbone, but that transitions quickly to a fragrant herbal bitterness. The taste lingers pleasantly for just long enough.  Feel - Perfect body, perfect carbonation. A nice creamy feel. Incredibly easy to drink.  Overall - Everybody already knows this, but SNPA is the quintessential craft beer. You can find it everywhere, and it's a welcoming and forgiving flavor. Perfect for getting people into beer while still offering enough for the seasoned vets to keep coming to.

Poured from 12 oz can into IPA glass Look: Pours a golden amber with about two fingers of a beautiful thick head that remains for a minute. A constant stream of bubbles comes up from the middle. A decent lacing is left in the glass. Smell: The smell is malty and sweet, with the hops dancing in the medium range. You can smell the cascade hops, but they're not overpowering. Taste: The taste follows the nose quite well. The hops are there but not overpowering and there is a strong malty sweet backbone. Neither the hops or the malt is overpowering and this beer is balanced well. Feel: The feel is quite smooth; not effervescent, not sticky. Overall: A good transition beer, well balanced and pretty good.
It's pretty good! Far from the best I've had, but I can see why many people enjoy it. Crisp and dry. Notes of herbs, orange and grapefruit. Very refreshing.  3.49 - B Pretty good
Drinkable nostalgia.

Classic well-done beer. Pour almost amber gold. Off white head with good soapy retention and lacing. Great carbonation and clarity. Cascade profil provides subtle bitterness and let’s the malt come through a bit. Slightly herby, bright, and piney, but all in a subtle and well- balanced way.

Ep 4: A classic brew, this pale ale is the perfect beer for newcomers to the craft beer scene. While light and refreshing, it also has just enough hop profile to make it worthwhile. There are certainly many better pale ales out there, but this will always beer a familiar favorite.  Ep 18: In the context of drinking a variety of macro brewed American Lagers, we loved how bold, bitter, and floral this beer can be. We can truly say that we understand why it's the beer that started the craft brew scene in the US.
Like my first girlfriend.... The first pale ale I ever loved....

Appearance: Pours a deep orange, slightly amber color with a rich orange hue. Mostly clear. A strong off-white head. Beautiful, and this is what an American pale ale should look like. (4.50).  Aroma: Remarkably light on the aroma. Orange nectar, pine soap, caramel, nectarine, peach, orange, grapefruit, lemon fruit zest, with a little pine. Some caramel and toffee underneath. Maybe some lemon dish soap, peach suds, and honey malt comes through. Attenuated and repeatedly less than I expect. Again and again disappointed by the aroma. (3.75)  Flavor: Clean but spicy and soapy orange, grapefruit, lemon citrus and pine soap flavor that mixes with caramel and honey malts. Decent, but relatively mild bitterness. Uniquely, the flavors are well-mixed. They all come at the same time providing one uniform flavor. Nectarine suds with soap? Compared to other SN beers the fruitiness is lighter/airier and less resinous, bitter pine that allows the fruit to shine. The flavor isn't great but the historical quality and balance is respected. (4.00)  Feel: The mouthfeel is moderate. Bitter, but balanced with malts and leaves a clean finish on the palate. (4.00)  Compared to Revolution's Fist City, more of a dry, bitter finish. Less fruit & citrus. More of a lingering spicy mouthfeel. Less flavor overall and just more spiciness. This one is predominately spicy and bitter forward. Much less flavor. Definitely your west-coast style, but lacks the aroma and flavor I desire.  to Three Floyd's Alpha King: This one has a more of an old school grapefruit and pine flavor. Much less dark tropical flavors. Much more smooth, clean, and some would say balanced.  to SN 40th Anniversary Ale 3/4/20: Similar appearance. Much less aroma and flavor. Less citrus, dank herbs, and pineapple.  w/ Summit's Extra Pale Ale 11/16/20: Pours a near identical color. Milder aromas. More caramel, orange citrus and soap. Less orange vegetable and flower. Less smooth and malty. A stronger bitterness.  to Boulevard's Pale Ale 6/2/20: Pours a similar color with a slightly stronger head. Stronger flavors of spicy citrus, caramel, and bitterness. Less applesauce, toffee, and marmalade. Slightly heavier bodied and sweeter.  to Celebration 11/23/20: Pours a lighter color. More orange peel, citrus soap. Less spicy caramel/orange and pien. A lighter body with more citrus hops. Cleaner. 3/15/22: Milder aromas. More candied orange citrus. Less spiced pine.  to their Oktoberfest 2020: Pours a darker color with a much stronger head. Stronger aromas of pine soap and sap. Less caramel and bread spice. More bitterness and less sweetness overall, however very similar. The Oktoberfest is only a maltier version of the pale ale. 12/14/20: Pours a darker color. More pine soap and orange citrus. Less sweetened orange/french toast. More bitter and clean overall.  to SN Oktoberfest 2021: Pours a lighter color. Stronger aromas. More orange and pine soap. Less toast, brown bread.  to New Glarus Moon Man No Coast Pale Ale 4/6/21: Slightly darker. Very similar. More citrus, pine, and herbal quality. Less tangerine and juicy stonefruit. A stronger bitterness. Quite similar.  to SweetWater 420 Pale Ale 6/2/21: More resinous orange, soap, pine, caramel. Less juicy, candied orange, lemon/pineapple sweetness. Darker.  to Fulton Pale Ale Project #1 8/2/21: Stronger malts. Larger and sweeter. Less peach tea and herbs.  Two head-to-head comparisons of the classic label and the Retro Label 8/10/20: Very similar. The classic label: More orange nectar aromas and slightly more bitter orange citrus. The retro label: More pine soap and suds. Less orange flavor. 10/19/20: Classic (3 month old): More orange citrus hop flavor and bitterness. Less tart citrus Retro (6 month old): More flat citrus with tartness. Winner: The classic SN label (although it's also a month or two more fresh.  4-way battle 9/20/21 Three Floyd's Gumball Head: Has the most American orange hoppiness. A strong malty body makes it drink like a pale ale. Summit EPA: Has the flowery and pine and chewy soapy orange flavor Sierra Nevada Oktoberfest 2021: Has the most sweet orange and rich toasty malt flavor. Similar to EPA but slightly more toasted. Sierra Nevada Pale Ale: Has orange, pine soap, and a caramel malt body. Less of a malt body.  Overall: This is the old-school west-coast style pale ale. Grapefruit, orange nectar and pine-soap hops that is appropriately balanced by malts. Doesn't finish bitter. Doesn't finish sweet. The ultimate balance of old-school American hops. Finishes so smooth. The rating here is lower because it's too basic for 2020. Yet, the flavor is quality. The historical semblance rescues the rating, but it's not something you'll find on the shelves. Compared to our palates now, this is surprisingly weaker in flavor and aroma, but the respect is not diminished. It has a uniform flavor and will always remain the standard, and that is quite an achievement. (Current Rating: 3.97)

Had it once about 3 years ago, and looking at the rating it obviously made a strong impression. Oustanding product. Will pick up again soon to ensure this rating is accurate. It's accurate, drinking it tonight and it delivers
My to go beer. Not too hoppy and heavy as Torpedo, somewhere in between. I am at a beer store and can not decide which one to pick, here is my to go beer that never disappoint.

3.75 overall as a beer; 4.5 if rating it as a pale ale. If I want a pale, this is one of my go-to's. A really good pale ale. Not a style I drink as often as others, but I like to mix it up from time to time. A good representation of the style. Hoppy. Medium carbonation. Seems pale ale and IPA is a pretty easy style to do. Most of these taste about the same. Really hard to mess up a pale or an IPA.

Poured from a 12 oz bottle into a dimpled mug, the off white head sicks around a while and leaves good lacing. Color is amber, nice and clear.  Smell of pine and citrus.  Taste is grapefruit bitterness up front, then pine, a floral hop finish then rounded out by the caramel malt that's necessary to balance this hop forward American Pale Ale.  Clean and crisp with medium-high carbonation, this is an all occasions beer that pairs well with a wide variety of foods.   I'm reviewing this beer after drinking it many, many times. It's like running into an old friend and thinking, "What could we possibly have to talk about" but then before you know it you're laughing, reliving old glories and catching up on new events.  Excellent. Hightly recomended. If I had to put together my perfect flight of beer, this would make the cut.
Exactly what I look for in a brew.

Straw yellow at pour, looks redder and more opaque in the glass. A thick head of suds. Mildly scented...corn? Taste is slightly bitter, yet mild for a pale ale. Not especially floral or citrus-like. Mouth feel a little thin.

Pours a creamy white head. Color is a crystal clear pale amber.  Nose is crackers and toast with floral and citrus. Some dried citrus fruit in there as well.  Taste starts lightly bitter with toasty malt character. The middle opens up to a more crackery malt note with, with the hop flavors opening up to present dried citrus and floral notes. The finish opens up more of the bitterness and just slightly dries the mouth, making you want another sip. There is a sweetness that rides throught the entire sip that is never overpowering.  The mouthfeel is the slightest bit aqueous, but not so much that it's a turn off. The carbonation is right where it needs to be for an APA (this is THE APA, so it's expected.  Overall, you really can't go wrong with Sierra Nevada Pale Ale. It's the one of the standard APAs that every beer drinker has had at least once, and it's always pleasant to go back to it. A perfect partner for a good burger and a solid way to introduce somebody to the wonderful world of hoppy American bears.
Probably my most drank beer
Refreshing, mild carbonation and bitterness, just right!

Pours a beautiful clear amber, thin white head and active carbonation. Smell is malty sweet with notes of apple, pine and caramel. Very pleasantly cohesive and complex. Taste is wonderfully crisp, piney and grassy notes lead, into a lightly caramel/rich malt body, it all tails of into a piney/citrusy hop finish. Classic for a reason, this is a taste that is hard to get sick of. Mouthfeel is super clean, definitely a drinker. Leaves nothing but refreshment behind. Overall this is an undisputable classic in the american beer market. For those of us deep in the modern craft scene it can seem out dated or passe but as someone deep in a stint of modern IPAs and big stouts I can testify to the refreshing, crisp delight this beer still brings. Don't be scared, it's just a classic

Poured a clear golden amber color. Large white head that dissipated very slowly with significant lacing. Fresh hoppy, floral aroma. Hoppy and somewhat bitter taste. Clean and crisp on the palate. One of my favorite pale ales!

Excellent and not to malty for a Pale Ale. People forget, that before the IPA fad, this was the best hoppy (cascade pacific) ale going. Best part is its only 5.6% abv. If you just wanna get f**Kd up get a double IPA . Sierra makes them too.

This beer turned me on to “craft” beers in the early 80’s and Ive been on board ever since. A fantastic use of cascades. A very solid pale ale and one that I recommend to others when they want to move on from bland Americanized light lagers.
I wish I could be drinking more of this but i don’t want to be wasting my precious brain cells with something so easy to get.

Sierra Nevada's flagship product, Pale Ale, is that one beer for me that delivers every single time. It embodies almost everything I need, and especially what I expect, from a beer: freshness, character, lasting enjoyment from first to last sip, and the ability to stand up to a hearty meal. From the clean amber color to the lovely floral scent and the piney elements in the full-bodied taste, it is my 'house' beer, hands down. ... (Update to this already magnificently written review: one of my local package stores has just started to stock the 19.2 oz tall boy can of this outstanding beer, and they're keeping it in stock just for me. The size is ideal, as two of these lovely vessels satisfy my self-imposed daily limit of 38 ounces. The price per ounce is just about the same as the six-pack, so that's not a subject for debate. Thank you SN for adding just another little nugget of enjoyment in difficult times.)

From notes 11/10/12: Pours clear amber producing a finger of creamy, rapidly diminishing, off-white head that leaves pasty rings of lace. Aroma is pale and light bready malt with floral and citrus hops. Taste is similar but more robust with citrus and a little pine in the hop profile. Finishes dry, astringent, peppery and bitter.

IPAs everywhere owe this beer a thank-you card. It is the gateway to the bitter, soapy world of IPA. Slightly bitter yet still a little sweet taste. Floral but not intimidating scent. Toasty color and moderate head. Pours nice into your everyday pint glass. A great overall beer and a great way to try something new if you’ve been stuck to macros.
Too basic of an IPA
A good bitter IPA offering. Nice aroma and a hoppy finish.
Great American Pale Ale. My go to evening beer.
The perfect go to pale ale. Never a bad choice.

Sierra Nevada Pale Ale. Nothing crazy, nothing strange or different, and no over-branding and over-promising only to under-deliver. All this beer is, is a near perfect display of simplicity and quality. With the exception of a few rotating local brews I cycle in, this is my go-to when eating dinner or just relaxing after work.  With the already abundant collection of reviews, I'd rather skip the formality and just talk about my favorite part: The hoppy, "spicy" bite at the end. To me, this truly does set this pale ale apart from others. Some are too smooth and don't have enough attitude, but this has a perfect punch. Nice smooth beginning, citrus and light hoppy notes, and then, the moment that makes you want more. A slightly dry finish into a tantalizing sightly bitter, fairly hoppy, and perfectly spicy ending. This beer likely won't hit your novelty-seeking dopaminergic threshold, but it deserves a spot in any rotation when you just want a really good beer.

Wow! Wonderful tasty delightful ale! Exceptional in every thing. Looks nice, I love the presentation. Looks like a classic and iconic beer. The aroma is a blast of brightness, grapefruit citrus with light hints of malt. Smells like a summer day when all the kids on the block have a fruity ice pop or snow cone. The taste is where it gets good. Wonderful top end sweetness that leads straight into those American citrusy hop notes. Grapefruit lingering around with a backbone of malt. The finish is semi dry with hop bite bitterness in the end. That semi dryness leads you to want another sip. Over the time drinking, the hops begin to build, making the beer rich and feeling very satisfied. The feel is light to medium with a bit of body. The carbonation is medium. Very smooth and easy to drink. Its a winner and a new American Classic. Credited as the Godfather of Craft beer movement. I can see why. Its damn good!

Very, very good beer! This is a gateway to an IPA if I ever tasted one. This one is well balanced and toned out through hops and malts. The hops are present but it is smoothed out through the mellow malt backbone.
Really love the bitterness of this, yet still quite light...perfect straight out the fridge.  Perfect balance of citrus, apricottness, malt and bitterness...top notch, love it

Look: textbook golden orange. Head is decent. Smell: Tropical fruit, grassy hops, some malt as well. Something that reminds me of a lager for some reason, still very good. Taste: a good balance between hops and malt, as expected from an APA. Hops is more on the grassy side than as I would have thought from the smell, with some citrus notes to go with it. Malty flavours rather biscuit-y. Some alcohol as well, but subdued enough. Probably the most textbook I've ever drunk. Feel: medium to light body with still a touch of silkiness. Warmth from the alcohol without burning. Classic. Overall: It may not shock and awe. Most probably, if you're an user of this site it won't. Yet it's got everything and doesn't miss much else. Very enjoyable.

Sierra Nevada's Pale Ale remains, even in this tremendously saturated market of hops and pales, a go-to crusher for me. I'll go through a case while I'm mowing the lawn sometimes. I don't even have a very large lawn. It's just that good, and it takes me that long when I'm drunk.
Sierra Nevada has a winner with this one. It's got good balance of hops and malt and exceptional flavor. It has become my go to american pale ale.
My go to Pale Ale

From a 12oz bottle dated 4/20/22 into a pint glass.  Pours a translucent golden orange with about one finger of white head. Incredible retention and decent lacing.  Smells of pine, earth, floral, light citrus and bread.  Taste is more on the hoppy side-bitter. Nice balance of the remaining nose elements in the background.  Slightly sticky mouthfeel. Medium carbonation. Drinks easily. Bitter aftertaste.  A delight to drink if you like hoppy pale ales (which I do!).
The og of the craft beer world. A true classic that has inspired millions. A great beer anytime

The first and the worst from a world-class brewer. SN has so much more to offer - this should be retired to free up capacity for more Torpedo! I had my first SNPA not long after they started . Weird, different and weird. Now, it is just not that good when compared to others.

Nice evenhanded brew. Well balanced malt vs. hops. Comes away on the hoppy side but not overbearing. Not in anyway exciting to look at. Gentle aroma of caramel malt is quite appetizing. Easy drinking, well made.

Served in pint glass. Pours a clear, light copper color. Medium small foamy white head, decent retention.  Sweet and light citrus scent. Very nice.  Taste is clean, malty sweetness, lemon, bit of spice. Not much pine or bitterness, definitely more malty than hoppy, but it’s a well balanced and refreshing beer.  Medium light bodied, solid carbonation. Clean and smooth drinking. An enjoyable very sessionable ale.  Very good APA that still holds well its legend status as a pioneer of the craft boom. Exemplary for the style. Easy 8/10 beer for me overall, 10/10 in the style.

Pours a deep bronze color with a nice whit creamy head. Smell is somewhat muted.Smells like pine, mild lemon, very earthy. Taste is almost perfect for a pale ale.Refreshing, crisp, pine and hop zing, Feels perfect as well (Well constructed) Nice refreshing pale ale with a perfect balance of hops and malts. Perfect carbonation, head remains throughout entire beer . Overall this beer is an icon. I have been drinking this before "craft"beer was a word. This was always my stand-by in the 80's,90's.

L4 - classic pale ale amber holding good head from the bottle. S3.5 sweet and inviting T3.25 Underwhelming. I’m an IPA fan so maybe it’s that I don’t appreciate subtler flavours, but just not much of anything coming through for me. F3.75 O3.5 totally drinkable and can understand why people like it but back to IPAs for me.

Bottle poured into a teku glass  Clear copper liquid, micro streams of carbonation, two finger off white foam cap, good lacings  Aroma is spicy, mild pepper,  Spicy hops over a good malt grain taste  Slight bitterness, hop nibble, slightly dry  Good beer

Meets the requirements of an APA and then some. Good tasting overall beer. Definitely hoppy but not overpowering. Light carbonation with some bitterness. Anber in color with medium lace. Caramel and citrus aromas/overtones.

A very well balanced, quality tasting beer. Looks and tastes great in a frosted glass any time. Great hop flavor that SN is known for. You can go off and start looking at the new IPAs or other new things coming out all the time. But always come back to SNPA. It's simply as fine a crafted American Ale as can be had!

I’ve been drinking this beer for 20 years. I don’t know why I buy anything else. I can get a 12 pack for $15, yet I continue to buy 4 packs for $15-18. It is hoppy and drinkable. IMO it is the best beer for the price.

12 oz Bottle Looks light amber with light/moderate carbonation. Generous head is slow to dissipate, leaving a nice lacing on the glass. Smells great - fresh malt, sweet tropical fruit, slight hop aroma. Sierra Nevada always seems to have that fresh crafted beer smell Taste is crisp and refined. Not a massive bitterness but pine is a featured flavor. Also getting various citrus and slight pineapple. Can really tasted the malted barley on the back end. Goes very well with Italian and Mexican food. Not as complex or rich as the Torpedo IPA but that is to be expected, this is very solid for what it is designed to be, a very drinkable but tasty brew. Grade is an A-
Perhaps the definitive American Pale Ale. Hoppy but ridiculously drinkable. A great way to introduce someone to craft ales.
It seems as if this beer was a classic. It is a very correct beer, without excesses, balanced, with the standars of the style. A good beer that is allowed to drink. For me, too simple.
When the trends fade away, and beer becomes beer again, there will always be Sierra Nevada Pale Ale. A true staple in not only the hoppy, pale ale style, but in beer culture itself.

This is a decent beer. The most impressive thing about this beer, for me, is that it operates in two separate consciousnesses. On one hand, the hoppy, fruity, and piney aromas and first sips make the drinker immediately aware that this beer has piggy-backed off of a trend towards more unnecessary hop action while a fine beer hides underneath. Such a move pacifies the beer hipsters, no doubt, but this beer is, fortunately, worthy of more praise than simply acknowledgement over the adequate execution of a trend. I can taste a simple, solid American ale beneath all of the pretense. A hit of corn, of wheat, of that perfect ale balance hides in the aftertaste, wishing it could have been realized.

12-oz. bottle PKGD 03/07/18 poured moderately into a 16-oz. mug produced a finger sized yet short lived white head with moderate lace. On the dark side for a pale, the color is clear amber. Sweet toasted malt and piney hops dominate the smell. Taste is floral and piney hops at first with a very malty middle, followed by a spicy/bitter hop finish. Medium/light body is rounded off by the high semi-sweet malt presents and medium carbonation. On the dark side for the style, the malt bill is noteworthy. Lots of hops yet balanced. I do like single hop beers.

I had a draft served in a large frosty mug in a restaurant last night where I usually order a Sam Boston lager, but they've discontinued it on draft. This 'pale ale' is much darker than its name suggests. A rich amber with a good head, quite lacy. It smells enticing. The flavor is full bodied rich and pleasant, not far off my go-to Sam Adams. I'd be happy to drink it again.  Taste Test Samuel Adams Boston Lager vs. Sierra Nevada Pale Ale Appearance: Very similar, clear Amber with a white head. The Pale Ale is perhaps slightly paler. Sam's head is perhaps slightly more persistent Smell: Too similar for me to differentiate, as one who is olfactorily disabled. Feel: Sam is perhaps slightly more carbonated Flavor: Pale Ale has the faintest hint of hops Overall: These two beers, despite one being a lager and one being an ale, are remarkably similar. Both are good.

L: Slightly hazy amber color, three finger white head, nice lacing, good carbonation.  S: Hops, malts, yeast.  T: Hoppy, malty.  F: Light bodied, extremely drinkable and refreshing.  O: Pretty good APA.

Been drinking this beer for awhile, however when I found it on base in Korea I was over joyed. Sure back in the States you have an unlimited varieties of craft beers to choose from. However, when you are in a place where Bud is the best you can get you will enjoy one of the Founding Fathers of the craft beer movements even more.

A balanced classic that's a benchmark for the style but ultimately nothing special in 2018. It has a vaguely macro lager-y feel to it even though it's nicely hoppy, with citrus peel notes. Balancing caramel malt. Tastes like a hoppy Yeungling.
One of my go to IPAs. Balance of hops is perfect!

Can’t judge the look I drank from the bottle. The taste is phenomenal, subtle hop flavor makes it a dream for people starting out on ipa’s that don’t want to jump into full bitterness. Would be great as an every day beer just sitting outside after mowing the lawn. One of the best from Sierra Nevada that I’ve had so far.
One of my favorite commercially available beers! Great tasting and drinkable beer, best of all . . . it is available at my local grocery store for a very reasonable price.

Pours a clear, deep gold/light amber coloration with a medium, fizzy head. Smells faintly of biscuity, bready malt, with a certain graininess coming through as well and the merest hint of citrus and pine. Taste is a good balance of biscuity malt and citrus hops, with just a hint of pine coming through and an underlaying grainy and slightly flowery note. Finishes with crisp, light/medium bitterness. Smooth mouthfeel with a light/medium body and medium carbonation.  I feel that the beer is actually supposed to have this slightly understated malt/hop presence, which is kind of typical of a classic, old school Pale Ale, I suppose. It's well balanced, crisp and easy-drinking.
Crisp, fresh beer. A bit of a head with great fruity smell and taste. An excellent, everyday beer after work in the spring or summer. Not at beach, but on couch or porch.
Sufficient head, foamy and white. Hazy in the light. Clear consistency, light on the tongue with the aftertaste of Wheaties—ah the best. Crushable and delicious!

strong body, smells of bread, notes of malt, look of amber. It's a fine pale ale through and through, and at 5.6% it's a relaxing, comforting beer to kick back. Leaves a bit small of a head for my taste but that's really the only big complaint I can drum up. Great beer.
Hands down the best pale ale, cleanest tasting beer...
at least sustainable end 2018-05-10 aroma and taste of lime, soft citrus perhaps grapefruit, pungent bitter as in co2, wet / dry in the aftertaste, nice
just brilliant
You can find this beer at any bar anymore. One of my all time favorites. Hoppy but not to hoppy.
Perfect balance of tastes. One of the best!
Props to such a great beer for many decades. You can't go wrong with this one.  It is well balanced, smooth, easy to find, and priced right. Excellent Job !!!

Bottled 1/16/18, consumed 3/10/18  Poured crystal clear deep amber with a small head that left a little bit of lacing.  Aroma is most toasted bread, very up front and dominating. Some malt notes, maybe a bit of spices faintly, but I didn't really get anything related to hops.  Taste follows aroma and is all toast. Very old school, other end of the spectrum from a lot of hoppy pale ales these days. Slightly more spicy notes. There is a prevalent funkiness in the yeast or something that is not found in a lot of pale ales or IPAs these days (except Belgian ones obviously). I honestly didn't get much fruit, pine, or other hop notes.  Mouthfeel is medium, pretty refined feeling, good bitterness.  Overall, more bready and malty than I'm looking for in pale ale. I can easily see why this has been a timeless classic; that being said there are quite a few other more hop-forward, year-round pale ales these days that I prefer.

Poured from bottle to pint glass. Copper color and a nice few fingers of foam. Balanced in every respect: not too sweet or bitter, but crafted in a way that the malt is clearly delineated from the lemon zest/grapefruit/piney hops. Clean finish.

Pours a lovely clear gold. Fruity nose, notes of citrus and bread, light caramel.Nice and complex. Spicy dough, subtle hints of fruits. Nicely balanced, full, smooth body with good carbonation. Deserves to be a staple.

Poured from a 12oz bottle into a tulip glass about a 3 finger white head that fizzes out but remains strong. Great lacing This is the beer that got me into craft brews. This is my go to beer. Hoppy, easy drinking, readily available. Love how refreshing it is especially for those hot hazy days here in Puerto Rico. LOVE THIS BREW!!!!

This is the first pale ale that I have had and I have grown accustomed to the hoppy bitterness that this style of beer brings to the table. I taste some cereal grains, some malts, slight caramel & their is definitely some pine that lingers toward the finish. This is a good beer from a good brewery but I think their Torpedo is better. Cheers! B

Malty overproduced swill IMO, why is this rated so high? Couldnt find any Centennial 15 packs so had to settle with this on a budget, only 1 month old but tastes way older IMO. I think that this beer sucks, as classic and old school as it may be.
My go to beer if I am trying to play it safe and just crack a few beers with some friends.

** 05/14/12  Bottle to pint glass.  AROMA: very light hop and barley aroma LOOK: light copper appearance; small, but creamy head TASTE: whole wheat/oat/grain flavors, hoppy finish. FEEL: Creamy and well carbonated. Good balance.  Went well with my seafood dinner.  **
Don't know of a better pale ale. Perfect for the style.

Looks like a light lager with medium body. Excellent carbonation. Smells like light cascade hops. Tastes like hops but easy to drink. Nice crisp lager easy finish. Easy to drink a 6 pack but not as bad as commercial light lagers. My least favorite from Sierra Nevada but still not bad.

12/25/17: 12 Ounce Bottle @ The Cosmopolitan $1 Tip playing video poker. Had this beer dozens of times, never knew I haven't rated in the past. Amber pour with white head. Beautiful hops aroma, love the aroma and taste. Nice balance of hops and malt, bitter and pleasant. Very solid mouth feel, carbonation holds well, firm going down. Overall very good Pale Ale, well done Sierra Nevada!
IBU 38
That’s a great pale ale

From 12 oz bottle, packed on 10/05/17. Pours amber with the nice white head. Good lacing. Nice aroma of hops. that quickly disappears after a bottle is opened. Medium body, well carbonated. Average pale ale.

This beer is true to the style of IPAs. It's not too hoppy like a lot of other American IPAs.. Poured into a standard pint glass, I got a finger of head with moderate carbonation. The smell is beautiful with cascade hoppes being the most prominent. When you drink it, you immediately notice the hop profile along with a good balance of malt backbone. The finish is a light bitterness from the cascade hoppes that leaves fuji wanting another sip. If someone were to ask me what is an IPA Style Beer this is what I would show them! All around fantastic go to beer year around.

Outstanding beer. Extremely well balanced--all components of the flavor come together and form a smooth synergy, nothing in particular stands out. The mouthfeel is full and creamy (simply taking swigs from a bottle generates a thick head inside of the bottle) while the beer still manages to be refreshing. Maybe the most easy drinking beer I've ever had.

what an APA should be . perfect balance. color Deep golden lacy head smell - grassy citrus and malty taste - if i could have just 1 beer for ever this would be it feel - full body yet light overall - just great
This has been my goto beer for about ten years. I'm a hop lover and it seems that even in the store where selection is slim, you can still find Sierra Nevada.

Clear amber color,medium body and carbonation. Aroma is subtle,grain,malt,yeast, as well as citrus and pine but all well balanced. Taste is identical,very easy to drink beer,goes well with all kinds of food as well as just having a few to relax
Tried nearly every Pale out there and nothing beats SN. 5.6% is a great bridge between IPA and PA and they do this beer impeccably.
A true classic of the craft age. Always a solid beer.

Pint on draft at Hella Good in Portland, Maine.  Appearance: Pours a slightly hazy, amber/gold type color with a short, frothy white head.  Aroma: Clean and fruity. Some pine and hop. Maybe apricot, grapefruit.  Taste: Follows nose. Really a terrific pale ale - pops with fruity flavor and hops without being even slightly overpowering. Grapefruit's there, some more citrusy taste is there. Faint winey type note.  Mouthfeel: Super drinkable. You just want to drink this all day.  Overall: A classic beer. Template for a lot of much more expensive beers, and it's better than most of them.
a classic.

This is a solid pale ale. It’s one of a few “go to” pale ales for me. Several of our convenience stores in my city keep this on hand regularly. When I can’t get to the craft beer shop the next town over, I usually grab a 6-pack of this. Beautiful golden color. It has a nice pine-citrus aroma. It has a citrusy taste with a wheat finish. It has a pleasant lingering aftertaste. It has a great feel as you sip (or chug). Sierra Nevada pale ale is a solid choice for an everyday ale.
bias comes from being a Chico State Wildcat but all-time favorite beer hands down. perfect for every occasion

An amazing fruity smell right off the bat, with your avarage pale ale colour. The taste is equally impressive. Overall feel is excellent. Worth every penny. Definitely a must-try for a true beer connoisieur´.

This certainly is a gentleman of a beer! All the flavours experienced come out sequencially every time. Pours a dark orange/amber with a small/med head. The carbonation is very present and inviting through a glass. Nose has citrise and the floral cascade hops come through very well. First off, there's carbonic bite, followed by citrisey, orangeyness. Then a malt sweet followed by a distinct drying bitterness that almost begs you to enjoy this slowley. There's not a ton a body but certainly a ton going on from start to finish. Which is why I will continue to drink this ale as a go to!

The beer has a thick white head. The colour of the beer is amber.  The taste is pine, citrus and malt. All of it is nicely balanced.  The beer is medium bodied and the finish crisp.  Just a delicious brew.
Perfect pale ale
javascript:void(0);

Amber color with a little bit of haze. Very nice one-finger head that lingers and laces nicely. Subtle, complex hints on the nose of pine and citrus. Taste is very balanced, nothing really jumps out on the front palate. The finish is really good and complex, just like the scent. Deep, lingering flavors of pine, grapefruit and freshly-turned earth. Complex beer that I enjoyed.

This is my all time favorite beer and my go-to beer when all else fails. I am biased towards this beer because I have hauled many loads out of their Chico brewery over the last 18 years and they have always been exceptionally nice.  Sierra Nevada Pale Ale is the quintessential example of its style.

Served from tap into a conical pint glass at Red Rooster in Cutchogue, NY. A: Pours a clear, inviting amber to light copper color with a one inch head, solid retention and elaborate lacing. S: Bouquet of lemon citrus and pine overlay and caramel maltiness. T: Elements of palate follow nose, but caramel malt backbone predominates. Bitterness nicely subdued, but contributed to complexity and crisp finish. M: Light to medium bodied. Solid carbonation. O: At or near the top of the style. Subtle and complex.
An excellent pale ale. A nice, rich golden color. Lots of flavor, but light and easy to drink. I can drink this all day long. Available in almost every store.

This beer marks the best balance between malt and hops. Yes, the hops are prevalent but it’s really the malt backbone which takes the cake. Beautiful amber coloring with enough bubbles to make it look like you’re drinking a real beverage.  This beer does an amazing job hitting a slightly higher than 5.0 abv while also being full flavor and not watery. One of my all time faforties.
abit flat. nice hoppy mouthfeel
This beer was delicious. Highly Recommend it to APA lovers.

L-golden in color. Not much cling. S- impressive hop notes spanning pine and citrus flavors T- same hop notes from the aroma. But it's backed up wonderfully by a caramel malt backbone. Hops still are the predominant flavor but balance is welcomed in a pale ale. F- light to medium bodied. Good mouth feel. O- I love the balance in the pale ale. Hop flavors are solid but the malt notes really make it.

A flavorful pale ale with good hop character that is crisp, clean and refreshing. It's light bodied but in no way watery. I don't think you can go wrong with this one.  Still a great American Pale Ale after all these years.
Decent Overall but a little dry at the end.

I decided to spend the extra dollar on this beer because I wanted to try something different. Look: Amber color, pleasant to the eye. Looks good to me tbh. Smell: IPA beer smell, strong good beer odor. I like it. Nutty, with hints of lilac (just kidding). Taste: It has a very powerful taste. It is smooth with a good aftertaste too. I like it. Feel: So smooth! Best beer I've tried all week! this beer is something a little bit strong for me, but when in the mood for something decent, i just paid 3.49 for a 1 pint 8 oz beer.
Great looking beer with a sweet piney/hoppy smell. Taste is a bit of citrus, bit of hops, fairly sweet. Overall a complex beer but it doesn't try to do too much, one of the best pale ales I've tried.

My first truly great American beer, which I originally came across in Northern California in the mid-80s. Found some reasonably fresh bottles at the Safeway and realized I'd never reviewed it.  Pours a clear deep gold. Three fingers of foam creates the definitive "dense and rocky head." Good lacing.  Smell is initially fresh pine resin and sweet citrus, which gives way to more earthy and floral notes. Taste follows, with a pleasantly bitter finish. Feel has substance for the ABV but super drinkable.  This beer was radically amazing 30 years ago. Now it's a fine classic.
This is my go to pale ale. It's crisp with hoppy, caramel notes and absolutely refreshing. What a pale ale should be.

Bought as a tall can from the LCBO. L: Yellow, almost orange, gold colour with foamy, white head. Pleasing lacing as head recedes. S: Tangerine, citrus and some malt sweetness. The smell just invites a large sip. T: Not citrus like you would expect from the aroma. Pine, orange zest, grass. O: An good offering from a stellar brewery. Well put together pale ale. I enjoy the faint citrus taste with the dry, hop finish. One could wish for a larger selection of Sierra Nevada beers to make it into Ontario. Although a classic, I feel they make better and it would be great to get a hold of some.

Poured into a clear glass.  Very clear and rich amber color and moderate carbonation. Thick head. Smells piney and has a refined barley aroma. Tastes somewhat wheaty and heavily floral, fairly spicy in the hops, a citrusy hint, but all very smooth. Pretty complex, but very well-rounded.  Good beer.

Well. The classic pale ale, the one that started it all, I get it. Craft, yet mass produced and widely available at a good price point, I get it. The goal posts keep moving. We have APAs hopped like IPAs, IPAs that taste like DIPAs, DIPAs made to knock you unconscious. You go back to this one and what do you get? An underwhelming amber colored ale with a faint aroma of citrusy hops and bready/grainy malt, a bitter, dry taste with some balancing sweetness, medium body, and a short slightly bitter finish. Maybe I'm just hooked on the current trends, but for now I'm enjoying the ride. Returning to this classic is jarring. I'm glad it's around, but I won't get another one anytime soon.

From a 500ml can served at 10 degrees Celsius into a tulip. The beer warmed up to room temperature during consumption. Best before date: 16.09.2017  Look: The beer pours a clear medium amber with 4cm of off-white head that fades into a partial film in 2+ minutes.  Aroma: Faint intensity even after warming. Some citrusy, piney hops with balancing pale malts. A bit soapy. Lackluster.  Taste: Same as the aroma, nothing to add. The finish is short, faint, and bitter.  Feel: Medium body with lively carbonation. Crisp.  Overall: It's never a good sign if I'm in the middle of a review and I get distracted and start doing other stuff. It happened with this beer and I came back to finish what I started at room temperature. I'm disappointed but I will probably try it again on draft or a bottle when given the chance and nothing more interesting is available. I really don't understand the high ratings.

Flowers, forest and citrus aroma upfront. Pour is golden clear, but last inch landing makes it hazy and full of hoppy particules. Frothy, steady head. 2 fibgers tall, not persisting but leaving a decent lacing. Aroma included some moderate light biscuity notes. High hop flavor. Moderate bitterness and moderate, grainy sweetness. Medium body, watery, medium high carbo. Salty. Long bitter finish bit astringent. Perfumy alcohol.  Not bad!

Pours an orange/amber into a fifteen ounce glass mug the same temperature as the beer. Two finger off white head that settles to a steady rime. Nice lacing.  Nose is sweet malts and floral hops. Some citrus. Maybe grapefruit? Butter. Earthy. Touch of sulfur.  Taste is sweet malts forward followed by good citrus hops. Nice balance. Nothing outstanding.  Good carbonation lends it way to a smooth medium mouthfeel.  Overall a good drinkable beer. Quite sessional.

Pours a deep gold. Nose is caramel malts, hops, fruity. Taste is very hoppy with a good balance of the malts. Average carbonation with a somewhat bitter finish. Very smooth going down and very flavorful. Getting some white bread in there also. Overall, I can drink this every day. Great representation of the style and one of my top three SN beers. Good price for a 12 pack.

Clear copper/amber, one finger head.  Smells grainy/bready mostly, with a slight fruity touch. Alcohol kinda muddies everything, very surprising on a 5.6% ABV brew. Piney aromas after it warms.  Taste is much more fruity: lime, citrus. Mango? A bit peppery and spicy, sweet. Apples too. Alcohol is very present but doesn't blend in very well. Slightly bitter aftertaste. Honey.  Very light carbonation. Kinda heavy.  Interesting. It's sweeter than most APA's I'm used to, but not overbearingly so. All in all, it's a bit stiff: it tastes nice, but it's a bit "dense", if that makes any lick of sense to you. Nothing really pops, it's a bit too uniform.
A great bridge between IPA and LCD. Both sides should enjoy

When I want an APA that is easy going and easy to find and not watered down by some company that doesn't care about beer (like AB). This is what I reach for. Pours a nice light semi-golden color yielding a one finger white head in my pint glass. Foamy speckled lacing graces the sides of the glass nicely. The smell is centered around some spicy yet grassy sweet hops, malts only slightly come out as the beer warms. Same as the taste, the palate is moderately carbonated with bitter aftertaste and finish. Overall, good for style and good for me.  This may be a simple one, but it's an APA and I don't expect it to be in the same ring as Heady Topper, a Crooked Stave Sour or even Deschutes' The Abyss. I think most people get my point if they're reading this. Cheers to great easy drinking APA's that go steady with easy to find food.

A nearly perfect brew, I poured it into a pint glass at just above freezing temperature, it poured with nearly no head (perhaps because I had it cold as possible) yet appeared highly carbonated, the color was a perfect amber, the smell is sweet and hoppy, the taste is an almost perfect blend of hops and sweetness , the only complaint I have about the taste is I got a bitter aftertaste that seemed strange, this may be from my own mouth though and not the beer. Overall, highly recommended, my second favorite full flavor ipa thus far
Fantastic brew, hoppy but not overpowering. Very smooth, yet still has a small bite too it. An absolute must try
The gold standard IMO. Smooth, not overly hoppy and full of flavor. What every other pale ale wants to be.

This and other Sierra Nevada brews have become easier to find since they opened a brewery nearby. Very clean taste whether frig cold or slightly chilled. I like the bitterness and hops that are there but not overpowering. This brew has become the one I measure others against.

Sierra Nevada's Pale Ale has become the standard by which I judge other beers there may be better out there, but many that are worse. This gives a 2 finger head. The color is a medium cloudy straw, because some yeast is left in the bottle. The aroma is a slight piney citrus. The taste is a distinct piney crispness with light notes of citrus. Bitterness is moderate toward the middle to back of the palate with a hint of malt which offers a smooth finish. I just find this to be one of the best palate cleansing, refreshing beverage any time of the year. Overall, this has been my go-to beer since Ballantine XXX Ale went out of business.

Sierra Nevada's Pale Ale has become the standard by which I judge other pales, there are certainly better out there, but many that are worse. I've enjoyed this beer both as draft as well as bottled. My review delves mostly into my experience drinking from the bottle. The color is a dark cloudly straw, owing to the bottle conditioning that leaves some yeast in each bottle. A creamy head lingers. The smell is fairly subdued, giving off more hints of citrus than Cascade hops. The taste however makes up for this by asserting the crispness of the hops which are complemented by light notes of citrus. Bitterness is mild to moderate due to the beer's maltiness which offers a smooth finish. As mentioned before, this is my go-to pale which I find can be enjoyed on nearly any occasion.

12oz bottled 3/22/17 poured into a nonic pint at fridge temp 5.6% ABV. The beer is bright orange copper in color with thick off white head and strong lacing. The aroma is caramel malt and a hint of citrus. The taste follows with caramel and a slightly bitter citrus finish. Mouthfeel is full, adequately carbonated and semi dry. Overall, very good and most likely unbeatable in it's price range.

This beer pours a nice Amber color. The head was white. Nice lacing on the glass. The nose is minimal. The taste has a crisp hop presence. It isn't overpowering. The feel is moderate. Not too thin. Overall, not a bad beer, and an easy drinking one.
Meh.

for me the perfect balance of hops and malt, but then I'm from Chico, so ... this is the beer that turned me on to the world of craft beers, and it has always been my go to beer. man do I love this beer!

refrigerated bottle packaged 3/15/17 poured in a glass  A - golden yellow to amber, very minute head which dissipates to a bubbly lace very quickly, mellow carbonation  S - sweet up front, kind of piney, hops, floral aroma mixed in  T - smooth subtle sweetness followed by a mellow hop bitterness  M - light to medium, mild carbonation  O - easy drinking beer, tastes mild on the hops, not the most flavorful in this class but easy to drink none the less. I'd have it again.

Craft beer taught me that drinking beer is no longer just an alcoholic pastime but an experience of body and mind, even more than reading a book or watching a film: as our bodies are comprised of mostly fluids, the liquid we intake will become a part of us and change our constitution for a short while. Craft beers are well known of their selected and high quality ingredients and the mastery of their brewing. Brewmasters are like artists who compose a masterpiece by putting the right amount of ingredients together and combining them in the right way to achieve a unique brew, outstanding taste, smell, feel - and nonetheless, experience. I am convinced that when we drink a masterfully brewed craft beer, our impression is different based on the type and amount of ingredients, let alone how and where they have been made or grown. Sierra Nevada has shown me that an unparalleled greatness exists in the art of master brewing by creating a true experience in a bottle: their own, one and only Pale Ale. I am not an advocate of uncontrolled substances but I must admit that having had a pint of this Pale Ale I was overwhelmed by the great Nature of the Californian woods and mountains of the Sierra Nevadas, the foothills of the Rockies. I felt for the first time in my life that the Cascade hops grown in Californian soil and raised by the sun and rain of that microclima convey an experience through the natural water, grains and yeast of California, as if I were there if I closed my eyes, as if I could feel its wind on my skin, could smell the air of the Pacific or of the depth of the shadowy forests and could even hear the rustling of the trees, the gurgling of a nearby stream... as if that scenery on the label has come alive. Sierra Nevada Pale Ale is such a psychedelic beer. When you drink it, you intake nature in its purest form and you travel through time and space to re-live something wonderfully natural. A masterpiece in brewing beer, a perfect harmony of tastes and a depth like no other. This is a must for all BeerAdvocate. This is the Alpha and Omega of (American) craft brewing IMHO.
this stuff's pretty good man. real easy drinking. good taste.
From Untappd

Look - Pours a beautiful dark orange color, big fluffy white head, lacing all over the glass. Aroma - Pine cones, orange, lemon, sweet pastries. Taste - Like the aroma, pine, orange peel, grapefruit. Hops are pungent but not overwhelming. Bitterness is kept in balance by warm malt, hint of light caramel and white bread. Finish is very long with a really nice nuttiness from yeast. Finishes dry but not abrasive. Delicious. Feel - Medium bodied, very slick and oily, good amount of carbonation, borderline creamy, slightly dry.  Overall - Great example of the style.

Look: Light orange-yellow, cloudy, thick white head  Smell: Hops, yeast, bread  Taste: Hops, a little citrus; a lighter IPA than some I've tried but still good  Feel: Watery mouthfeel, warm, dry feel after swallowing  Overall: A pretty easy IPA to enjoy, I would recommend this to anyone who is trying to get into IPAs

Still a classic after all these years. Poured directly from the bottle, dated 11/14/16, into my gob. Pine hop bitterness and a whiff of malt for balance. Slightly sticky feel but mostly a clean finish.  Carbonation seems low, but I always feel a little bloat with this. Maybe a built in attenuator to my consumption.

This is a really tasty beer. It has a hop front taste but malts are apparent as well. Not as good as some of the fresh stuff I get up here in the Michiana area, though. **** new rating= This is so smooth/hoppy/malty... mild bitter taste...very consistently great and competitive.

This is hands down my favorite beer. I grew up in Redding, CA which is about an hour north of Sierra Nevada's HQ. They've been pumping this pale ale out for decades now and they have established themselves as a leader in brewing industry.  I didn't like this beer the first time I tried it (18-19). That's the thing about it: you get used to it. It has so many flavors going on at once that it can be difficult to understand for noobie beer-drinkers. Eventually you'll find a new flavor to enjoy every time you take a sip. I simply have yet to find a pale ale that is as consistent, delicious, and reliable as Sierra Nevada Pale Ale. I personally associate it with many great Northern California memories over the past 15 years.  Get one ridiculously ice cold, pour it into a frozen beer glass, and enjoy on the hottest summer day of the year. I'm sure you won't be disappointed.

Poured from bottle, 1.5 finger head with significant lacing. Hazy light brown almost bronze colour. The smell is of straight up cascade hops and a little bit of acidity. The smell translates directly into flavor, with the cascade hops up front on the palette. There is a citrus almost lemon-lime element present, and a weak malt backbone is also present but doesn't add much for balance or sweetness. As it warms it seems to get more bitter. My bottle did not have very significant carbonation, which I found slightly strange since I've had this beer plenty of times before and it did. Maybe someone shook the bottle. YMMV with that. Mouthfeel was as you'd expect a pale ale to be otherwise, a little on the thin side. Overall this is one of my go to beers when I'm looking for something a little more hoppy. It's flavor is heavily skewed towards hops over the malt and makes a nice change of pace without completely obliterating your taste buds like a full on IPA does. The 37 IBU rating seems low. If you like cascade hops, try this!

Poured from bottle into shaker, minimal head, nice lacing. Clear amberish golden in the glass. Taste caramel malt sweetness on the front, leads into predominantly pine, with a mild bitterness. Great beer.

Nice balance between malt and hops. There is slight malty sweetness but there is a hint of savory -- almost a slight funk. The hops are fragrant and floral. Overall a very good that I'll go back to even though this isn't my favorite style.

Poured from a 12 oz bottle,into a Funky Buddha snifter.Packaged 02/03/17.  Thick creamy off white head that stands 1 finger tall with very good retention and sticky lacing.Light orange colored body with good clarity,and small amounts of sediment.Very low carbonation with a hard pour.  On the nose I get piney and floral hops with earthy,sweet,and caramel malts.Not much else,kind of a subdued and uneventful aroma,though not unpleasant.  On the palate I get sweet and caramel malts up front,piney hops in the middle,and floral hops balanced by earthy malts on the back end.  The mouth feel is medium with a sticky texture,dry finsh,and good amount of oxidation on the tongue.  This is a pretty solid APA,not my favorite but definitely up there.Good malt / hop balance with a nice bitter backbone.I've had it before this,and will drink it again.Recommended if for some reason you haven't tried it yet.
Almost clean orange/gold beer with excellent golden head. Smell - grain, sour citrus. Taste - grain, citrusy, generously hopped. Moderate to high carbonation. Not impressing at all.
Really good beer
You can definitely taste the hops on this iconic brew. It smells and tastes great, so it's easy to imagine how it became the gateway to craft beer for many a soul.

A - 2 fingers off-white foam over a body of golden amber, transparent, high visible carbonation  S - light scent of grapefruit, pine, and grain  T - lots of citrus and pine, peppery spice, bready backbone, dry finish  M - crisp light/medium body, high carbonation  O - Just an enjoyable pale, a good standby when nothing else available
Dark amber color, medium head. Hoppy aromas and flavor. Smooth, creamy feel. A good, average pale ale.

This is yet another over-rated average beer in my opinion. While everything is quite average, ie not great, not bad, I especially don't like the unbalanced after bitter taste. While it's drinkable because of it's complex fruity smell, it's only good for pairing for light food, ie, not too tasty nor too salty food.
One of the first many moons ago

IMO-Sierra Nevada Pale is simply the "king" of craft beer ! The quality in most , Sierra products is one reason I continue to support this brewery. This is the "gateway" beer into craft beer for many people. Not much can be said about this beer that hasn't been said 3000 times. I spent a month in Erope and I was shocked to find out that the only American made beer served in the hotel was Sierra Nevada Pale. A great, smooth beer, great price , well made !

Poured from a bottle , mostly clear orange/gold with white head leaving a fair amount of frosty lacing. Definitely a standard for the style ,nose is balanced between malt and hops. Taste follows. If memory serves me correctly this hasn't changed much in 30 years, although I used to think it was really hoppy. Possibly the 1st craft brew I drank after moving to CA in the 80's.

Pours a clear honey gold with a white head. Smells of light hops and light citrus. Tastes of citrus, slightly sweet malt, and slightly bitter hops. Medium-light in body and medium in carbonation. Overall it’s a decent pale ale.

12-oz bottle into nonic pub glass  A - 2 fingers off-white foam over a body of golden amber; transparent, but full of sediment; high visible carbonation; laces the glass nicely  S - light scent of grapefruit, pine, and grain  T - lots of citrus and pine from the Cascade hops, peppery spice, bready backbone, dry finish  M - crisp light/medium body, high carbonation  O - Just an enjoyable pale; a relaxing end to a busy day.

This was the first beer I ever drank. My best friend ordered it for me. it took me hours to finish it. It seemed so bitter. Probably not the best beer to start with. Years later it tastes so smooth, well balanced and is one of my all time favorites. A true classic. Cheers to this wonderful beer and a company that didn’t sell out.

Pours a orange amber color with a creamy white head. Smell is piney citrus hops. With many beers the taste is similar to the smell. However, mildly bitter unlike, IPAs. Mouthfeel, light and refreshing. Overall, a good beer for its style.

12oz bottle poured into a pint glass.  Hazy orange amber in color, the pour forms up very thick creamy off-white head that stays with remarkable retention before slowly sinking to an eternal foamy layer on the surface and leaving plenty of sticky lacing patch and spot.  Lots of biscuity malt as a base in a nose, hop discloses slightly thereafter with notes of pine, floral, spicy, earthy, citrus, and grapefruit.  Delicious and great balance, sweet and biscuit malt lays as the backbone of the flavor structure while hop comes into play providing its spicy, earthy, pine, citrus, grapefruit, and medium resiny bitterness.  Medium body with good crispness and some lively carbonation, smooth mouthfeel, dry finish.  Classic APA indeed, it is well-rounded and perfectly balance. A truly inspired beer.

Not a bad beer, good toasty malts. Hops are spicy, piney, and resinous with a tiny touch of grapefruit. That being said to me its a little to crisp and bitter, not super smooth or easy drinking. Kind of thin and not thirst quenching. Definitely not a bad beer just nothing special to me, more of an east coast guy I guess.
Been drinking this one for more than 20 years - excellent as always. I always come back to it and it never disappoints.

L: Orange/amber color, generous head S: A light but detectable smell of the cascade hops: citrus, floral, and pine T: Initial slight bitterness followed a nice malty aftertaste. Refreshing and simple. F: Very easy to drink. Medium-bodied and crisp. O: There may be better APAs out there that are more complex, but this is a fine beer that can be enjoyed by both hop lovers and non-hop lovers alike.

The bottle poured a deep golden color with a generous three finger head that fell to about a finger and hung around for a good while. Lots of stick-to-the-glass lacing.  Smell was a nice balance of resinous, floral, and citrus hops supported by a biscuity malt smell. Wonderful, the citrus was just a hint.  The taste followed along, with a bit of bitterness up front, then the hops come in with the floral, milder than expected resin, then a bit if brightness from the citrus that seems more orange or tangerine than the usual grapefruit. Well-balanced, nice malt presence that put me in mind of a pilsener. A little biscuit, a little sweet.  Medium to light on the body, drying enough to invite another sip. Carbonation in the just right zone.  Overall, this is a great beer and I believe you have to add in the value. Available just about everywhere year round and at a very reasonable price. Good take on the style, SN delivers a well-balanced, flavorful beer.

This, along with Sam Adams Boston Lager arey staple brews. I live in PA close to the DE border where I get a 12-pack of each in cans for less than $30. I appreciate IPAs, strong ales from Belgium, seasonals, stouts, etc., but these are my day-to-days.  Why? Four reasons: 1. balance, 2. quality, 3. availability, 4. price. Price has become a dirty word on beer review sites but these beers represent a great value. They're fantadtic representations of their respective styles produced in high enough volume to make them widely available at a fair price without resorting to gimmicks.  Plenty of others give descriptions of look, flavor, taste. Sierra Nevada Pale Ale is a high-quality brew that rivals the great beers of Germany but is uniquely American. It's just fantastic. The day I tire of SNPA is the day I tire of beer.

I give it a 5 overall as a tribute to its position in the history of American brewing. It is smooth, just hoppy enough to make one happy, and will always bring back the memories of when it was the only alternative to Bud or Miller at too many bars.

Poured from 12oz bottle with freshness date of 8/9/16 into Stein.  L: Pretty golden color with thick three finger white head that slowly recedes into a lasting finger head. Great lacing that stays put.  S: Spicy, floral and earthy almost crushed leaves hop smell initially, transforms into a mellow biscuity aroma.  T: Smoothness like a straight razor shave consisting of sharp crisp bitterness from the hops to begin the complexity of this beer. You get a wonderful menagerie of floral, citrus, earthen and spicy hops. Mellowing out from there the malted barley comes through to take hold. Very well balanced.  F: The medium to low body of this beer with the refreshing balanced complexity to create one of the most easily drinkable beers out there.  O: I recently developed a taste for hoppier beers that thus far I heavily disliked. After realizing this I decided i must try one of the all-time American Pale Ale staples. I was swept away by this beer and will recommend this to most anyone. Well done Sierra Nevada.

It's a classic that really showcases the importance that Sierra Nevada places on balance. While it has inspired countless breweries to start a hops and IBU arms race, Pale Ale is here to stay for what you go back to when you want a taste of perfection. Not only is it the benchmark for taste, but also price and availability. If service is the rent we pay for living, Pale Ale is the rent Sierra Nevada pays to the world of beer.
Golden colour with little head leaving some film.  Taste is has hop fruits enhanced by the malts. Bitterness is mild and quite pleasant.  Overall quite good. Very well balanced and tasty.

Pour in beer glass, slight cloudy amber gold, with short foamy head. Floral hop and pine bouquet. Nutty and subtle caramel on palate. Smooth and light bubbly mouthful. Overall, a naunce of well-balanced malty & light bitterness.

12oz pkgd 09/07/16. Pint glass. Brassy orange color, moderate white head, crystal clear as SN is want to do. Piny and citrusy hop aroma, which could easily be an IPA. Flavor comes through strong with that same one-dimensional hop sharpness, but finishes with a biscuit malt aftertaste of toasted grain and a hint of caramel. But the bitter and sweet flavors don't work together and compliment each other. Rather, the malt flavor only serves to disqualify this beer from being a hoppy, West coast IPA.  As a pale ale I find this beer to be a failure, and as an IPA, it's just not very good. I deeply regret this this beer has become a benchmark for American Pale Ale, because I think there are some great APAs, and they don't taste anything like this one. I would much prefer this beer broken down into its components and served to me as separate ales: the aroma, bitterness, malt body, and color are all fine, but don't belong together in the same glass.  I do think this beer may be better in a fresh bottle than on tap.

Poured from bottle into short bar glass. It pours a pale orange color with one finger of milky-white head and lacing with excellent retention. The smell features grass, pine needles, floral hops, and a whiff of citrus. The taste opens with a nice malt base with grapefruit and a blast of bitter hops. It is super dry and crisp. It's moderately carbonated and with a 5.6% ABV it's very easy to drink. There's a reason this is considered a classic: it's consistently well-crafted, tasty, and refreshing. This is a great beer with which to introduce a friend to the world of craft.

This is by far the best pale ale I can think of, sure there are better beers, better Sierra Nevada's, and better IPA's but this is a pale ale and only 2 beers come to mind and that is Rolling Rock and Sierra Nevada. Rolling Rock used to compare when it was brewed by Latrobe but now it's brewed by Annheiser Busch and is awful. Sierra Nevada stays true to its roots and now brews the only delicious pale ale I can think of. Not to mention it is the beer that got me into IPA's, took me,away from commercial beers, first to inform me there are better brews out there , and it is Sierra Nevada's signature. An American classic. Although better straight out of the bottle this time poured into a tulip: Look: golden with a fluffy head. Aroma: pine and citrus. Feel: medium, malty, and hoppy. Taste: spicy, floral, earthy, piney, malty, hoppy, citrus, and a lameness dryness only found in Sierra and Rolling Rock.

Nice color. I'm getting a subtle scent of citrus and pine on the nose with a nice malt in the background. Everything is working for this beer so far. Ok, so I'm getting a lot of subtle flavors. It's got some hop bitterness and citrus notes to start then flowing into a nice malt finish. I would not call this a bitter beer. It's somewhat carbonated and slightly dry on the finish. Nothing overpowering here but a solid good tasting and well balanced beer. I like this.

L -- Lovely pale orange. Two finger head with moderate lacing S -- Fruity hops. Mild and clean T -- Similar to smell F -- Crisp and refreshing. No lingering off-tastes O -- The fresher the bottle the better the taste!  81/100

From a bottle dated 7/26/16. Pours an orange color with a finger of white head. Smells of citrus and pine. Light feel with medium carbonation. Taste is a balance of malt and piney hops. A classic and my go-to at places that don't have many craft beers.

Old Reliable - my standard for Pale Ales. Its just a great blend of the malt and piney hops. This was my gateway into drinking good beer after years of Miller and Coors. The flavor blew my mind...reminded me that beer should taste good! Highly recommend to anyone who's never had one. Excellent beer.

Pours a pale light yellow with an off white head.  A nice bouquet of pale malt with citrus, pine, and floral hops in the nose.  Taste is biscuit malt up front with bitter pine and citrus pulling it towards hoppy with a dry nutty finish. The Pale ale standard.
Was my go to for years. Great IPA, I'm no longer a huge fan of the after taste, but it was the IPA that made me start drinking more IPAs so I gotta have love for it

One of the best beers that is consistently available wherever I find myself. This is in my rotation of twelve packs I pick up, and they don't last long. The short neck, colorful green, and mosaic of rolling hills makes it stand out from most other beers. Overall, a must get. Though their Sierra Nevada Torpedo IPA is even better.

Age: 1 month old. Vessel: can Glass: Teku  Starts off with a huge pop of bitterness to open up the pallet then followed by sweet bready malt to stays in check by the hops. The body is med to full and finishs dry leaving you waiting for another sip. Excellent!  This beer still hold up to this very day and the quality of the beer speaks for it self. This beer came out in 1980. Imagine drinking it then for the first time, a bottle conditioned, all natural, hoppy pale ale with no fillers!  What can I say, A beloved classic, a pioneer in American craft brewing, a beer that has truly stood the test of time, a Sierra Nevada Pale Ale.

355ml bottle poured into tulip.  Pours a clear amber-orange with one finger of off-white head that leaves cascading mountain waterfall lace as it recedes.  Smells of cut pine and citrus rind, biscuity caramel malt, wet stone and freshly cut flowers.  Tastes of lightly honeyed bread crust, orange and grapefruit rind and more sappy pine.  Feels soft and fluffy. Medium bodied with frothy carbonation. Finishes dry.  Verdict: Recommended. Tasty and easy to drink.
A -cloudy cooper, think foamy head >30sec w/lingering lacing S -clean and crisp, somewhat pine T -fresh M -light O -Quafable pacesetter for rest of Pale Ale month

12 oz bottle poured into willibecher glass bottled on 7/27  A: Creamy tiny bubbled white head, body is a bright amber with great clarity.  S: Smells piney, floral, earthy, with a light bit of rust.  T: Light sweet malts play across the tongue while the hops add a piney bit of bitterness on the underneath.  M: Medium bodied also a little lighter very bubbly on the tongue though.  O: It isn't a bad beer but probably one of my least favorites from this brewery. It isn't exceptional in any way shape or form.

12oz can  Appearance: clear orange, medium to big head of tiny bubbles. Very good amount of carbonation.  Aroma: the weakest point of this beer. Light piny and citrusy smell, with a background of slightly sweet malts.  Taste: grapefruit and piny hops, light malts,maybe a hint of mint. Simple and nice.  Mouthfeel: medium bodied, the right carbonation, crisp and refreshing. Grapefruit aftertaste.  Overall: a very nice and enjoyable APA, a simple one. Refreshing, good taste and mouthfeel.

This flagship APA pours a light orange color with a medium foamy off-white head. The smell is fairly hoppy with citrus notes and some slightly lighter pine notes. The taste is fairly similar with some orange and grapefruit citrus tones dominating and an undercurrent of pine and malty slightly sweet, toasted bread flavors. The body is light to medium and the finish is semi-dry. Overall it’s a crisp and refreshing beer. The hoppiness is quite restrained compared to many other APAs that I’ve had (especially from California), but when this first came out I’m sure it was considered pretty hoppy. I personally prefer it to some of the hop bomb APAs that I’ve tried, though I’m sure that many would disagree with me. To me this is a simple beer, but one that is has great clean flavors and nice balance, for sure a classic.
A real solid apa great taste and feel. One of those beers you can drink all night.

Not much to say that hasn't already been said.  Can pour into tulip. A steady, quality pale ale with little to distinguish it from the crowd. Scores points for reliability, availability and generally being a beer that is acceptable to most palates. A satisfactory drop for novices and seasoned beer lovers alike. A regular in my fridge

Pour is a deep yellow with very foamy head and excellent lacing. Smell is citrus in nature with a nice hops and some light grains. Taste is a smooth hoppy feel with nice citrus burst and pleasant dryness on finish. This has been a go to beer for me for a long time and it just gets better and better over the years, great beer.

Benchmark American Pale Ale. Out of the bottle, poured a beautiful deep copper colour with slight haze from bottle conditioning, and with a creamy persistent head. I got aromas of grapefruit citrus, orange peel, pine, and wildflower honey. Moderate caramel malt, moderate hops with lingering bitterness. Very well balance. Creamy, refreshing. Excellent.
My favorite beer of all time.

L: Hazy golden color. Thin head that reduces to a thin lacing.  S: Grains with a hint of hops and citrus.  T: Bready/ malty flavor with a little bit of hop spicyness that blends well. A bit of a dry finish.  F: Smooth mouthfeel with a little bit of dryness in the finish that sticks with you awhile.  O: I have always been a stouts/porters guy and I am just starting to venture out into pale ales/ IPAs etc... I know this is one of the gold standard American pales ales, so I thought I would give it a go. Nothing big and bold about this but it is enjoyable. It would make a good session beer.

Classic pale ale. Drank this one at a slightly higher temperature than usual (more like 55-60) and it was astonishingly flavorful, with absolutely no off-putting elements to the flavor profile. Still perfectly balanced and immensely drinkable. Great beer!

Ah my first ale of any kind pale, or IPA. This was introduced to me years ago by my friend Brian Watring. I think my thoughts at the time were bitter, Christmas tree along that line. This gave me a fine appreciation of the soon to try IPAs which I came to enjoy. Poured into a English pub glass. Orange, golden colour, almost like an Oktoberfest. Aroma off the bat, metallic, much like Yuengling Lord Chesterfield, or maybe thats cause I just read my review of that one, smell again..no, definitely metallic, but not off putting. Dry, Its been awhile, but the piney notes I dont really find anymore. More of a dry hop, dry malt, biscuit taste. Light easy drinking beer. Very good, although I know not as intriguing as when I first sipped the "green goblin". The price is still reasonable for a craft brew.

Don't revisit this as often, and for some reason, never rated it before. 12 oz can from 6/13/16 poured into a Guinness style pint glass. Pours a clear, golden orange with a half finger of fluffy white head. Retention goes down to a thin lace at medium speed. Aroma is full of pine, mild citrus, and a tinge of cracker. The flavor matches the nose, with a very crisp semi-bitter finish. The feel is medium light, with a medium level of carbonation.
